content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
												Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 is the first FPS game ever to give me motion sickness.I only noticed I was getting nausea about an hour in, when the FPS POV I was seeing the game through wouldn't stop ♥♥♥♥ing bobbing, like I was playing as The World's Drunkest Car Mechanic. Thankfully, I was able to find a way to turn off the head sway. However, it does not stop the camera from zooming in and out suddenly like it was bobbing its head to a song I couldn't hear while I was trying to take apart the car. Need to remove the timing belt? ENHANCE. ENHANCE. That's gone, now the actuator. OH YEAH, PARTY TIME. OONTZ OONTZ OONTZ. Fix the water pump? ZOOM IN ON THAT♥♥♥♥♥♥LIKE WE'RE THE NSA. Unlike the sway, I cannot turn that♥♥♥♥♥♥off AT ALL.It did teach me a few things about cars and I like a game that makes me use the parts of my brain involving deductive reasoning. I like to fix♥♥♥♥♥♥and it made me feel smart. However, this simulator skimps on a lot of the finer details of automotive maintenance and it's actually not all that good at making me feel clever when I've finally managed to fix the problem with the car. There's nothing really to gain from playing this. Especially if playing it makes people feel queasy. Don't bother.

Posted: February 4, 2014
												Great game, very enjoyable. If this is based on real life car maintenance, it is a great way for a guy such as myself to learn the fundamentals of maintaining my own car just in case. I am a big fan of simulators generally speaking and this is one simulator that I have never seen before. The graphics fidelity is good but not great, then again it is focused on car maintenance and not really a racing simulator where every visual has to be perfectly crisp. As a person who never touched a car bolt, it is quite fun to learn the quickest way to get to a part and replace it. Took me quite a bit of time to realise how easy it was to get the engine start part out. However the down side to this game which I noticed, taking a car for a test drive for assessment is completely useless. Reason being that you won't be able to know what is wrong with a car just from a test drive or at least you don't receive a test drive results. I have done a test drive before I repaired a faulty muffler, to see how loud the car goes. Did the repair and tested it again, there is no difference in engine sound. Customer said the the car is too loud because of the muffler isn't doing its job. But you can't really tell because there is no such thing.Secondly, Suppose as a mechanic you want to save some money by buying used car parts in very good condition to use for repairs. Sorry to ruin the fun for you, you can't do that. This is because A) in-game used car parts shop does not show if a particular part is in good condition or bad.. Maybe a percentage scale??? and B) Even if you are lucky to snag a gearbox which scores 80% out of a 100% with a really good price tag, you replace the old damaged gearbox and Job done? No, the game does not allow you to do that and you wont be able to progress to the next job.I hope this review reaches the game dev team to make it better in future updates.Will I recommend this game to friends or simulator enthusaists? Answer is yes, despite those little quirks in the game but I do agree I personally found it fun to play and this is just starting out, did not reach the point where I do complex jobs and tweaking engine power using power commander etc.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												All the fun of being a shade tree mechanic without any of the mess, busted knuckles or that awesome feeling of dread that you've broken your car beyond repair. You're presented with various customers' auto problems that range from the very specific "I hit a giant pothole and destroyed my left side suspension" to the very vague "my car makes a rattling sound on startup." You can visually inspect various areas of the car, or go on a test drive, or use an OBD scanner and later in the game you get access to a suspension and brake tester. You have the choice of buying new parts or buying used parts of dubious quality from the junkyard to make the repairs with. My favorite part of this game is that it lets you keep all the messed up parts in your inventory. Pretty soon you'll have a nice collection of busted water pumps, torn up clutch wheels and a mountain of worn out shocks and springs. The game gives you an option to sell these (presumably to the same junkyard you buy stuff from), or you can be a completely unethical thief and slap the busted parts on a later customer's car, taking their good parts for another customer. See, the game has certain milestones you have to do in order to pass a scenario, like "replace oil and air filter." It doesn't care if the rest of the components of the car go down in quality, as long as the parts the scenario cares about get fixed. So sure, I replaced Mr. Smith's dead battery, just like the game wanted me to, but unbeknownst to him, I also swapped out his perfectly good gearbox and ignition system with almost broken ones from Mr. Johnson who was my previous customer. In the scenario where I had to fix the guy's left side suspension, I simply flipped the parts from his good right side onto his left side, then sent him on his way. If this game has taught me anything, it's not about learning how to fix cars, rather it is to WATCH YOUR MECHANIC LIKE A HAWK in real life. I think I spend more time essentially screwing over each one of my customers than I do actually repairing their vehicles. Remember that junkyard? I regularly buy crap from them and swap it into my customers' cars, just so I can have a good copy of a part when I need it, without having to pay full price for a good one.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												For myself, someone who knows less than nothing about cars, I found this game to be fun and informative. I found the controls a bit wonky and wished I could remap some of the default directional controls, but it didn't prevent me from enjoying the experience. As I've owned the game additional features have been added so I can't say whether remapping keys is an option at this time.The graphics are very clean and sharp, allowing one to see where the various car components are in an uncluttered transparent skeleton model. I know looking under the hood of my car certainly doesn't look remotely like this game. Where's the boundless layers of grease, rust and leaves. Why do I have leaves under my hood?There are a few good songs that play in the game, one of which has a heavy riff guitar that I enjoy the most. The songs are basically just background music now that I've turned the volume down some. The variety of songs is varied enough to keep things from getting too stale.I would agree with some other reviews that there is certainly some repetition to the repairs, but that's exactly why I got the game. I wanted to learn about car parts and where they are on the vehicles. So this is probably not a sim well suited for the mid to high level car tinkerers out there. I would recommend this sim game for the uninitiated auto jockeys like myself.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												While it isn't precisely the same as working on real cars in a real garage, Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 does bring more of the look and feel of working in a real commercial garage than one would expect from a simulation.The engine work is greatly simplified (ignition problems are limited to but a few components, simulated cars never seem to suffer from any issues related to the internal workings of the motor) but the intake, suspension, exhaust and driveline (including, diabolically, the clutch/pressure plate/clutch-release bearing) are detailed enough to get the feel of in-shop assembly and disassembly.I really enjoyed playing through this game, and the 4x4 expansion. I hope that further expansions will add more detail to the magic-box style gearbox and engine internals... Maybe even add a gas/electric hybrid into the mix, too.

												I'm having trouble seeing how this is a "Car Mechanic Sim" because it doesn't include having to go to the autoparts store (at least twice) first time to pick up the tools needed to get the spring back on the rocker arm, the second time because you didn't know you needed that part and then 3rd to get back the core deposit. Also, have I in no way accidentally put something on backwards. Then have to take all apart again, just to put it back together and then find out I left off the seal, so I gotta take it apart a 3rd time to install the seal. There haven't been missing parts, screws or bolts, nor have I had extra left over screws or bolts.  It's these missing factors which make me question the title of the game but thats also the nice part about it too. Though the games 3D models seem a little simplistic at times, again its also the nice part about this game, because it otherwise becomes a chore. Do not get me wrong, navigating between area's of the automobile definately cannot be conviently traversed. Controls are a huge issue to me for any game, though they not crucial for this one.All around, its a fun game, it gives you some very general auto mechics knowledge, without the headaches of have to deal with an automobile and you can still get to work in the morning (results may vary). I've been running this on my i5-hd3000 lappie, at times I've seen the frame rate drop below 20fps, though still playable. Gameplay = Simulated MechanicsGraphics = Okay (could run smoother)Sound = Good (dig the soundtrack - though a little varity would be nice)Controls = Good (typical FPS [first person service] controls)Replayability = Yes (nice escape from the other FPS)Overall = 7/10

Posted: September 1, 2014
												This is the real deal. I mean, not literally the real deal, Car Mechanic Simulator won't leave you covered in grease or anything. Like most sims, the fundamentals of CMS are simplified--you don't, for example, have to worry about things like re-tightening the bolts on a wheel in a star pattern, and you don't have to think about what kind of oil the car takes, you just empty it and refill as needed. But the basic idea is there: figure out what's wrong with the car, identify the parts to fix or replace, and bolt the new parts into place. Simple! Or maybe not.The first few tasks are very simple, but as the game goes on you'll run into more difficult or more vague problems. Sometimes, this isn't so great--a few of the orders, for example, want you to restore a part of the vehicle to tip-top shape, not mentioning that all parts must be green (hey, the car still drives with yellow or orange parts, and some cars come in so beat up that every part is orange, so clearly the game doesn't expect me to replace every non-green part, right?). But most of the time, the challenge is fair. Why does the engine cut out occasionally? What's causing that odd sound at low RPMs? If you don't already know the possible answers, you will soon.There's still more the devs can do to make this an awesome game--the garage management aspects aren't very interesting, and sometimes you'll get a request describing odd behavior with the car only to find the test drive doesn't show any of these aspects (it's not supposed to, it turns out). But this is a surprisingly absorbing sim. Definitely recommended if you like the idea of tinkering with car engines without having to get your hands dirty.

Posted: March 19, 2014
												I'm yes and no on my recommendation for this game. This is the groundwork for a game I'd love. Kind of a long reading following but this'll give anyone looking into game an exact idea of what they're jumping in to. This game is a nice buy for car/mechanical enthusiasts. This game would be best set up for someone who is just getting into cars, but isn't very familiar with their mechanicals. You could learn how basic parts go together and what some of their effects may be. However, to advance through this game at a decent pace you need a little prior mechanical knowledge. For example, you may be told that you need to find a power issue and not know that the fuel pump or fuel filter could be the problem.The problem with this game though, is that no matter whether you're a mechanic yourself or someone learning, The game will have become mind-numbingly monotonous about 3/4 of the way through. At this point you'll have seen all the vehicles, driven them, taken care of every problem, and you'll be running on repeated problems so you can buy all the Learning Book upgrades. All the concepts are presented less than halfway through the game, then the later garages simply allow you to diagnose parts faster. At the time of writing this I quit the campaign about 6/7 of the way through out of sheer boredom.If you've ever played the 1989 Street Rod DOS/Commodore 64 game, then you've played this game. Infact, in the first garage, the game can be seen lying on one of the shelves as a neat little reference. I would recommend searching around for Street Rod, since it's a nice little game to play. The only problem is that this game only has slightly more detail than Street Rod did 25 years ago. In Street Rod, you changed wheels and clicked the bolts much like you do here. You changed out engines, removed heads, carburetors, and upgraded your car in general. After upgrading, you'd go do a basic NES-era street race to earn other cars or money and continue until you beat the fastest racer in town.In Car Mechanic Simulator, I'd say you have a little more variety of detail but not where most would enjoy. Put graphical detail of 3D models aside. When it comes down to it, you're changing air intakes, timing chain/belts, suspension parts, gearbox parts rarely, and the exhaust. You will never touch the engine block, the sub-frames, or any body work (on that note, the feature list specifically states that you will do body work). These parts are off-limits and can't be removed. You will never be able to customize any setup; it's Part-On, Part-Off, and what condition the part is in.The car models themselves are nicely detailed, but are static and feel a bit bland with the way they are rendered. The cars are modeled after real-life cars, but use slightly different design and names. Most of them will be European/Japanese economy cars or small vans/SUVs. The 2010+ Mustang replica is the most distinguished car, but oddly one of the SUVs seem to the fastest car you can test drive. As parts wear, they begin to show slight signs of rust, which is a nice detail. That said, parts are fixed. There's two engine designs: I4 and V6. The two engines are the same in each iteration, and the V6 will sometimes have a RWD dif or 4WD dif with an additional driveshaft. Also, both engines are always transversely mounted, which is a bit odd considering most V6s in this game are RWD rather than FWD.Gameplay wise, there are a few minor annoyances. While part selection in general is nice, there are times when you'll find yourself clicking to a part 5+ times because of the cursor trying to select a part that's behind the one you want to click. Certain parts, while obviously accessible from your current position (under the car, left side wheel well, etc), can't be touched unless you exit the current area, walk around, access the "proper" area, and then remove the part. Often, the camera will zoom or align to an impossible angle to remove the bolts you just selected, so you'll have to fiddle around and zoom out to remove the part. Occasionally, the bolt removal will glitch and you'll have to move the camera to be able to click the bolt again. You'll find yourself constantly moving between nearby areas and lifting the car up and down repeatedly to reach nearby parts. One of the bigger annoyances was the removal of air filters and exhaust parts.  To remove the air filter, you have to remove the plastic engine cover, the tube, the MAF sensor, the cover, and finally the filter (VS just taking the cover off in real life). God forbid you have to remove the exhaust manifold or the catalytic converter. You will have to start at the back of the car, removing every section of exhaust until you reach the desired part. In real life, you'd either drop the whole assembly or simply remove the problem section by itself. These little things, while not that big a deal by themselves, can become annoying after a short amount of time.Also, never buy used parts. Just don't. Often the game requires the replaced parts be of a very high condition and often the random part will be in the green and still not be accepted as a replacement. In regards to replacement parts, often you are not told what the complete requirement of repair is. While not knowing a problem is true to real mechanic shops, some work orders (goals to complete a repair) simply don't give you the full goals. One example in an early mission is how you're given a work order to "Do an basic examination of my engine." Do a full examination, and the requirement isn't fulfilled. Turns out you have to just replace broken parts even if the service is not requested. This causes confusion, as early on in the game, you're given specifics that ask for examination but not service. Perhaps the work orders need to be re-written.Finally, a small personal gripe of my own. The game feels like a hospital bedroom. Everything feels stark and bland. Everything on the cars are perfect save for part discoloration. There's no character to any of the vehicles or the locales (save for the first garage itself). Perhaps if there was unique body damage, difference between cars (other than color), or visual dirt/grime and broken part models it would feel a bit more lively.Over all though, this is a fun game for the auto enthusiast for a few hours. I'd recommend it to anyone who likes cars and wants to learn the basic setup of car mechanicals. I feel at the current time it's more of a $10 game rather than $20. I'll have to see how the game evolves with updates, but as the core game is now I'm going to let the last of the campaign sit. I want so badly to have a modern, high-definition version of Street Rod or Gearhead Garage. This is a step in the right direction. I'd pick this game up to support the developers and to help show that there's a market for this kind of game.

Product received for free
												First let me tell you, that I have absolutely no ♥♥♥♥ing clue about cars. I don't even own a license and I am 28. So when this game threw words at my face, telling me to check/change them, I was totally confused. But that's exactly where the fun starts. Call it "exploring" if you want to.I played it 10 hours straight and finished the non-DLC part (76 "missions") without realizing how time is passing by. Once you get used to it, there's something like a workflow that shows up. Like a daily routine, you know exactly what to do and you feel like a ♥♥♥♥ing car mechanic who could open his own shop (Don't do it. You will fail and fall on your fugly face. Your family and friends will come at you and remind you that they "told you so").I got the game for free, so no big thinking there. At first I was like "Yeah, probably just another stupid simulator where 50% doesn't work and the other 50 are bugs.", but I gave it a chance and damn it was fun. If money is not an issue for you, than it's probably smarter to go for the newer 2015 edition that seems to have tons of more features and stuff. I will buy it myself I guess.Pros:- Addicting- You'll get a hang of it after a few question marks over your head and then the fun starts- Kinda of an upgrade system- The graphic is okay'ish for this type of game. You usually don't expect either nothing or comic style from simulators.- This game can make you feel satisfied when you finish your job in the right way. It just feels good like when a girl touches your balls.Cons:- The camera is pure♥♥♥♥♥♥for like 80% of the time- I don't know about other languages, but the german translation is so hardcore garbage that I almost want to make it a "pro" for a humouristic attempt.- Clicking on small stuff, combined with the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥camera, can be painfully annoying. You know what I'm talking about when you try to switch your first spark plug.- No search function in the parts shop. Scrolling and scrolling and scrolling and dieing while scrolling and scrolling and balls.10/10 would repair friends cars now

Posted: July 10, 2014
												Fun game. Not realistic, but fun in it's own wayYou trying to repair cars, sometimes there is orders with direct instructions like "replace oil filter" and sometimes there is orders with description of the problem like "weird noises from engine" or "bad steering". You need to examine car parts and replace (or repair, if possible) them.Some parts can be examined by just looking at them, some needs to be dismantled.There is some tools to help you with that - read data from on-board computer, run a test drive or use diagnostic stand to check out brakes and suspension. After that, you will see condition of relevant parts immediately.There is one bad thing about test drive - car alway acts like a perfect working car, even if order states that it makes weird noise or doesn't start at all. All that it does - it reveals condition of some parts.There is also some illogical orders, like so: It states that car don't startYou checks engine, find out that electrical wires and spark plugs are damaged, and everything else looks ok. You replace them and nothing happens - order doesn't complete.I watched that order on youtube - and somewhy, you need to replace starter as well, even if it's on 60% condition (doesn't looks so bad).Fortunately, there is only one or two of that, other orders are fine.This game doesn't have all the systems that real car have, and after playing it you will not be able to repair your own car. But it's kinda educational anyway - you will know approximate layout of the car systems. And yes, it's fun, so if you like that kind of games - it worth a try. There is even free demo version to try it out - so try it, and buy it if you like it.

												In this simulation/social commentary Vidcon, you play as the owner of a GARAGE who must repair AUTOMOBILES to make ends meet. Without a formal education or any experience in AUTOMOBILE repair, you must take out a loan to finance both your business and your training. However, if you choose poorly, you will find yourself in the red- unable to pursue both options. Which will you choose: future opportunity or present stability? Will you cut corners to keep your nascent GARAGE afloat? Will you end up penniless, forever trapped in a greasy dubstep purgatory? All these questions are answered... and more... in CAR MECHANIC SIMULATOR TWO-K ONE-FOUR!

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												The idea is good, very good, but way to far to be called a simulator... The most simplest job in the game is changeing brake pads on a disc brake system. In the game all you do is... 1. take the wheel off 2. take the caliper off 3. remove the pads from the brake rotor 4. Replace the old pads with new pads 5. Reinstall the Caliper 6. Put the wheel back on. In real life this is the basics, but so far from the actual thing, its great for the casual gamer who dosen't know anything about cars, but when you do this stuff for a living its somewhat silly and mundane. If your wondering how many steps their actually is to replace the brake pads in real life... 1. Break all lugs on wheels 2. Jack car up 3. Remove all wheels 4. Disconnect all brake lines from calipers and allow time to bleed off. 5.  Remove calipers 6. Remove brake pads from Caliper 7. Compress cylinder within Caliper to allow new Pads to fit 8. Install new pads to fit 9. Reinstall all Calipers with Pads 10. Not a bad idea to check the rotors as well, Replace if worn or galded 11. Reconnect brake lines to all Calipers 12. In respect to the posistion of the Master Cylinder start from the farthest corner and work inwards bleeding the calipers to fit, make sure no air is in the lines. 13. When bleeding your Brake system pump your brake pedal and depress on the third pump, while another person cracks the bleeder on the caliper, repeat until clear fluid is coming out. 14. Frequently check the Master Cylinder to ensure it is not empty when you are bleeding the brake system. 15. If everything checks out, put your wheels back on and torque them to their respective torque rateing.  But in all honesty, if the game did this i would be impressed, and probably not want to play, that sounds like a lot of work. There are also some things that♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off, like stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥that your best position to remove a starter is from the top of the engine compartment, and rubber bushings just slide out, and even the fact that everything you do is by hand with a wrench. Not going to lie, i like this game, i suggest you buy it if you wanna get some general car knowledge, but this thing is far from a simulator.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												STOP! BEFORE READING THIS REVIEW BEWARE NONE OF THIS IS COPY AND PASTE I WROTE THIS HOLE REVIEW!Really cool-looking game about fixing broking cars in your garage. But... will you like it? Would I recommend it for you to buy? That's depends of what are you expecting from this game, in the first hand.Let me tell you how it works, right from the start: you'll find yourself locked inside the garage, with some broken car and notation of what you should do with it. You can disassemble the most of the car's engine, suspension and exhausts. You can fix some of those disassembled parts on the workbench, or buy new ones in the PC installed in your garage. Reassemble the car with new or fixed details, and they'll send you next one. After some time you'll get enough "free" money to "buy upgrades", namely, the discounts for the spare parts market, ability to squeeze the next client for more money, ability to notice some of the wrecks with your blind eye, without any expertise, and, finally, ability to turn screws faster... Which is really suitable, especially when exhausts needs fixing.After 2-3 dozen of cars, they let you in the new, bigger garage, with more tools to examine the wrecks. And in the third garage, which you'll get in about half of the game, you'll face "the master tool" - thing for making magical "chiptuning" (which looks as some kind of puzzle - or the way to make quick buck, depends from perspective).That's it. Quite an accurate attempt to draw the line of work for cars mechanic, with its bright and dark sides, choices and so on.Downsides? There is one noticable, but boy, it's Big! You see, all is quite simplified: two different engines (V4/V6) and front-wheel drive/four-wheel drive - which gives us four, only four possible variants of what we should assemble and disassemble over and over. After you'll fix 2-3 cars in the main career and 1-2 cars in each of two dlc's (4wd and tuning one) - you've seen it all.So, if you were planning to use this software to safely find out how to fix your own VW/Ford/Toyota/whatever - forget it. If you were looking for game about making cars out of scrap or just wanted something powerful enough to keep you awake all night long - nope, not this case.So, why I like Car Mechanic Sim and think it's good for any games collectioner? First, it's really looking good now - being made on quite limited resources. Yeah, an example of good code work. Second, even while there are not enough depth and variety, it still can teach something - I'll definetely provide this piece to my son - before showing him wiring schemes and options for gear boxes and other more complicated stuff. Third, it's good 3d puzzle game - find out the easiest and cheapest way to get wheels spinning - that's steeper in my book, than crushing numberless skulls... Even if not that fun. And note various languages at game's settings! Learn how to call your wheel in Spanish, German, Russian, et cetera! Yeah, learn the cars topic on your favourite foreign language! (Too bad they don't have Chinese and Japanese, though.) Finally, the price. It's good now, even without bundles!So, Car Mechanic Sim 2014 deserves 6.5/10 points and good place in my game's library. Will it fit for you? I don't know. But you may try, it won't bite.PS: the music there gets old fast, I turned it off after the 1st hour of playing... a small thing, but I still wish for more options there

That's depends of what are you expecting from this game, in the first hand.Let me tell you how it works, right from the start: you'll find yourself locked inside the garage, with some broken car and notation of what you should do with it. You can disassemble the most of the car's engine, suspension and exhausts. You can fix some of those disassembled parts on the workbench, or buy new ones in the PC installed in your garage. Reassemble the car with new or fixed details, and they'll send you next one. After some time you'll get enough "free" money to "buy upgrades", namely, the discounts for the spare parts market, ability to squeeze the next client for more money, ability to notice some of the wrecks with your blind eye, without any expertise, and, finally, ability to turn screws faster... Which is really suitable, especially when exhausts needs fixing.After 2-3 dozen of cars, they let you in the new, bigger garage, with more tools to examine the wrecks. And in the third garage, which you'll get in about half of the game, you'll face "the master tool" - thing for making magical "chiptuning" (which looks as some kind of puzzle - or the way to make quick buck, depends from perspective).That's it. Quite an accurate attempt to draw the line of work for cars mechanic, with its bright and dark sides, choices and so on.Downsides? There is one noticable, but boy, it's Big! You see, all is quite simplified: two different engines (V4/V6) and front-wheel drive/four-wheel drive - which gives us four, only four possible variants of what we should assemble and disassemble over and over. After you'll fix 2-3 cars in the main career and 1-2 cars in each of two dlc's (4wd and tuning one) - you've seen it all.So, if you were planning to use this software to safely find out how to fix your own VW/Ford/Toyota/whatever - forget it. If you were looking for game about making cars out of scrap or just wanted something powerful enough to keep you awake all night long - nope, not this case.So, why I like Car Mechanic Sim and think it's good for any games collectioner? First, it's really looking good now - being made on quite limited resources. Yeah, an example of good code work. Second, even while there are not enough depth and variety, it still can teach something - I'll definetely provide this piece to my son - before showing him wiring schemes and options for gear boxes and other more complicated stuff. Third, it's good 3d puzzle game - find out the easiest and cheapest way to get wheels spinning - that's steeper in my book, than crushing numberless skulls... Even if not that fun. And note various languages at game's settings! Learn how to call your wheel in Spanish, German, Russian, et cetera! Yeah, learn the cars topic on your favourite foreign language! (Too bad they don't have Chinese and Japanese, though.) Finally, the price. It's good now, even without bundles!So, Car Mechanic Sim 2014 deserves 6.5/10 points and good place in my game's library. Will it fit for you? I don't know. But you may try, it won't bite.PS: the music there gets old fast, I turned it off after the 1st hour of playing... a small thing, but I still wish for more options there

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												This just goes to show that there is a game out there for everyone. Car Mechanic Simulator is exactly what it sounds like; you fix cars. However, there are a few things that really make this game something beyond your typical simulator garbage.First of all, the ability to see into the inner workings of a vehicle is insanely cool for someone who grew up loving The Way Things Work. Next, there is actually a functional game here. Beyond just doing the repairs, you occasionally need to diagnose issues, you have to buy parts, increase your skills, and even figure out ways to complete repairs with used parts when customers don’t pay enough. Additionally, there is a new game mode in the complete edition called 1/4 Mile. In this mode you are given a budget and then are free to purchase whatever parts you feel are necessary to get a vehicle to run the quarter mile in a designated time. This mode is so awesome and oddly takes me back to the days of Need For Speed Underground 2 when I would spend hours at the track fine tuning my cars for different types of racing.Like all simulators, read tons of reviews to make sure it’s for you, but Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 is a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												While I love cars, this just wasn't the best game I've seen.     My one main problem with the game is the repetitiveness (is that a word?). There's some variation, but it's mostly- Find red parts (Sometimes through a test drive), replace, next mission. It would be fine if there was some sort of way to move through the game other than buying books for faster screwing.    Another problem was the interface. I was hoping more of a simulation, but that wasn't there. Instead of a visual damage (Which would be nice in a Simulator) the part is just regular, yellow, orange or red colored, which is headache inducing at times. Also, while I was hoping for a mechanic's view, it's just a camera with wierd controls. This makes taking out bolts and small parts very repetitive and boring.    Overall, I can't really reccomend this game, as it lacks both the gameplay elements of a game, and the realism of a Simulator.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												An astoundingly relaxing title for those who enjoy a little logical problem solving wrapped up in a neat little educational package. At no point could the game be considered a replacement for a formal mechanical education, but as you progress through job after job a little common sense goes a long way, and patterns emerge as you learn to associate particular faults and issues with components. While this will not help you put together that kit-car you’ve promised yourself for 20 years, it will give you an insight into the likely causes of common problems and test your ability to narrow down the offending item.Reasonably priced, well-polished for its price point and even a little educational – a very reasonable product indeed for anyone who wants to get a feeling for the causes of common car problems, or if you just enjoy a little problem solving.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												CMS14 isn't going to make you a real life mechanic overnight. It's not a true simulator, but it's more of a puzzle game. In the early part of the game, you are already given the areas that need to be fixed, and it's more like unbolting parts, fixing them, and rebolting them and finishing the mission. You are given several basic situations of what to fix in a given situation. Later on though, like a real mechanic, the customer will only give a general situation, and it's your job to figure it out. Pretty much anything that is red, you have to fix. I think the only negative is probably the variety of parts to fix. All cars have (more or less) the same parts, like the engines all look the same. Things like supercars with turbos aren't in the game, as are aftermarket parts. Everything is a FWD car.If you like puzzles and you like fixing cars, this is a good game for you

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												An astoundingly relaxing title for those who enjoy a little logical problem solving wrapped up in a neat little educational package. At no point could the game be considered a replacement for a formal mechanical education, but as you progress through job after job a little common sense goes a long way, and patterns emerge as you learn to associate particular faults and issues with components. While this will not help you put together that kit-car you’ve promised yourself for 20 years, it will give you an insight into the likely causes of common problems and test your ability to narrow down the offending item.Reasonably priced, well-polished for its price point and even a little educational – a very reasonable product indeed for anyone who wants to get a feeling for the causes of common car problems, or if you just enjoy a little problem solving.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												*** I have 20+ hours of play in this game on another account. Not the few minutes it says.***I am someone who doesn't know anything about cars.  I bought this game so I could learn some basic starter information.  I not only have learned about where a water pump normally exists, but also found the game fun to play.  I found the controls a little odd, but not too difficult to work with, but it didn't prevent me from enjoying the game.The graphics are very clean, and the way the game colors parts of the car allows for me to easily identify different components.The music is limited in its selection, but one of the channels is perfect for me in that it plays a hard rock style guitar song and so I just listen to that channel.Overall, I have learned just what I wanted from the game.  Where parts are, the names of different parts, and how various parts link together.  It's a fun game if you are looking for exactly what I wanted, which was to learn some very basic things about a car engine and where things are located in a car.

Posted: June 20, 2015
Summary:Generally a terrible game. The Why:Purchased on the Steam sale for a low price but even that can't justify the headache this game creates. As the blurb says you run a car workshop, carrying out orders to test or repair customers cars. Unfortunately, even if you over look the base graphics and the eyestrain inducing distance blur (it renders a workshop and despite this small space it blurs walls and details out when you walk too far away) the meat and potatoes of the game is sadly lacking. From a mechanically point of view the game is very basic, almost child like in the way the disassembly and assembly of the car and components occur. It's very much by the numbers and sometimes incorrect (good luck installing a helical spring into the car before the shock assembly) or removing a wheel without jacking the car up or using the car lift or even removing wheel nuts in the correct manner or any sort of torquing. From running the workshop point of view the business side of it is sadly lacking, I repaired a starter and charged the customer $100. Repairing the starter cost $92, so I made $8 on that job not including my time, any consumables, taxes or running of the workshop itself. The UI is terrible, the camera controls frustrating and the restrictions on how you can inspect components irritating. Test drive is pointless. Perhaps a good game to get a young child interested in car mechanics but I would not recommend for anyone else especially anyone who has actually tinkered with cars themselves.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												So, two things up front, then I'll get into the review.First up, this entire review can also be read on Youtube, with almost 19 minutes of gameplay that covers a lot of the features in the game.


YouTube™ Video: Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 - Running on a Surface Pro 2 Tablet 

			Views: 586		

			I made this video to show Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 running on the Surface Pro 2, and show some of the game play with a combination of the keyboard and stylus. So I'm a huge fan of Gearhead Garage.		

Second... I wish there was "Maybe" button for recommending the game. That's the one I would choose, and the review will explain why.Ok, so I'm a huge fan of Gearhead Garage. I've been waiting and hoping for a new version of it for at least 12 years now, but obviously at this point it's not gonna happen. When I first learned about this game a few weeks ago, I was estatic! My hopes were high, and when it released today I only lasted a couple hours before I bought it. Now I'm here to tell you how I feel about it.On the surface, it does seem very similar to Gearhead Garage. You get jobs, in which ou need to take parts off cars, and put new parts on cars. Not real cars, but make-believe cars that loosely resemble real cars. For those of you that don't remember, Gearhead Garage didn't originally have real cars either, the only real cars in the game were third party unofficial modifications. So far, looking good.Personally, my favorite part of Gearhead Garage (other than 3rd party mods) was the ability to buy crappy cars at auction, fix them up and resell them at auction. After 25 or so missions, I haven't seen anything like that in Car Mechanic Simulator 2014. It's just been mission after mission after mission. The only thing I see to spend your har earned money on is mediocre upgrates to make you 5% more money on jobs, make bolts loosen 5% faster, or other trivial upgrades. In other words, there really isn't much of a reason to make money in Car Mechanic Simulator 2014.Don't get me wrong though, the game is somewhat entertaining. It's not extremely educational, if you know virtually nothing about cars it will give you a basic idea of where car parts are, what parts are named, and a very basic understanding of car diagnostics, if you pay attention. But a lot of aspects of the game aren't very obvious. I've changed the oil on more cars than I can count, but it took way longer than it should have to find the oil drain plug in this game, and once I did it looked NOTHING like an oil drain plug looks like in any real car I've changed the oil on. I also didn't find out there was an oil draining pan until I read about it on this forum. This is good, and bad, a double edged sword. The game does not hold your hand through the car repair process... it gives you the opportunity to figure things out on your own. Still though, it would be nice if something had told me I could click on the oil catch pan, instead of wasing $100 on every oil change for a clean up fee.Also, the test driving physics are laughable. They made Grand Theft Auto feel like Gran Turismo. It's a nice touch... but don't expect any of the cars to handle even remotely realistic. It's a gimmick, at best. A cheap way to see the quality of some of the parts on the car. Not entirely useless... just not well executed. But what can you except from a game that released for $15?Overall... the game is decent. It's the best car mechanic game since Gearhead Garage... but it's not more fun than Gearhead Garage... not even AS fun as Gearhead Garage was, IMHO. The graphics are ok. The part location accuracy is decent. The gameplay mechanics are not bad. It's a combination of point and click searching, along with some puzzle solving. Once you start figuring things out, you can build a decent strategy to solve most car problems. The game still throws you for a loop though. Sometimes because it's a genuinely good puzzle. Sometimes because the game should have let you know where to go to find an option.I want to fully endorse the game... but I'm having a hard time doing that. For $15... I guess it's ok. If I knew what I know now, I'd wait for it to go on sale at $5, but I had to find out for myself. I'm not strongly disappointed with my purchase... just a little. I'm still hoping the game will get better with mods, expansion packs or maybe after a few more missions... but I'm not holding my breath either. If you loved Gearhead Garage... you might like this game. But personally... this game has mostly just whetted my appetite to try to get Gearhead Garage running on my PC again. Other than that, I think it'll be a decent diversion when I want a game to just burn time with. The mechanics of the game are ok, if you haven't played Gearhead Garage then I think you might find it a refreshing turn of pace from the average lot of games on the market today. If you did play Gearhead Garage, and loved it like I did, then I think you'll appreciate this game, but find it mildly disappointing... as I did.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												CMS is great if you want to grasp some basic automotive knowledge. And I do mean it. If you, like me, were seeking for challenges and in-depth content, then maybe this game is not for you. Here's why:1. It's too easy and repetitive.The first assignments will feel fresh and may be fairly challenging if you haven't had any experiences with car maintenance. After a while however, 2 hours in my case, the game gets boring. Problem searches become extremely easy as bad components will be very obvious to spot. This is also due to how the cars are built; every single car has almost everything put in the exact same place. Even GM couldn't pull that off.2. It's way too simple.There are no rusty nuts and bolts, anything can be taken out with a simple wrench, because, what are ratchets? You never have to appy oil, silicone grease and whatsoever. Basic car programming tasks are completely absent. There are also no customers that would pressure you, make work difficult, etc. (conversations would be nice). The only thing that requires you to actually do more than pressing LMB and RMB are freaking oil changes, but even those get repetitive after a while.3. Not enough content.Another problem of CMS is the little depth of content. You never have to pay for garage bills, every car has unlimited supplies of headlight fluids, the wrenching upgrades do not offer enough and, like I said before, no angry customers and competition. The biggest problem for me however is the lack of variety in cars; You can't find a diesel car, truck and anything that doesn't have its engine up front. So, if you ever wanted to do some car projects that would make you insane in real-life such as an V8 Audi or even Kim Jong-il's Merc 600, look away.Verdict: CMS is alright for anyone that wants to get a very general understanding of car maintenance. But then, you will have to shell out 6 or 12€ for a so-called simulator that makes car maintenance and engineering look as simple as a Volkswagen Beetle engine. There are thousands of literature and internet sites with more depth that are dedicated to these topics. Most of them don't even cost you a penny. If only the game offered much much more in terms of entertainment value, I wouldn't mind recommending it.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Not a bad base game. Kept me occupied for a while but is a limited experience with less replay value compared to the old Gearhead Garage game that I remember fondly.The entire game suffers due to long load screens between the garage and different test areasThe main negativity comes with the two expansions.The offroad expansion adds little apart from some new vehicles and a tweaked test track, while being littered with multiple spelling errors and occasional broken orders. Order 13 broke for me and seems to be an ongoing unfixed problem for some on forums.The 1/4 Mile expansion becomes repetitive extremely fast. The early orders I played simply set a time to beat and I just buy and fit enough tuning parts to beat said time. I quickly lost interest and stopped playing this mode. There are two big problems apart from the repetetiveness  with this expansion for me:1. Due to hitting the drag strip after each upgrade I spent most of my time staring at the load screen (seems to take nearly as long as the drag test itself).2. The learning book upgrades unlocked in the career mode are not implemented in the 1/4 mile version so despite being in the endgame garage, changing parts takes a long time as though I'm back at level one. The skills should carry across from the completed career mode in my opinion.Overall, worth picking up on sale to play through the career mode and then move on, maybe dabbling with endless mode if you get the itch to play some more. Forget about playing the expansions in their current form because they add little, while having drawbacks and bugs. I cannot recommend buying this at standard retail price.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
StoryNo real deep story, only thing you know is that you are a car mechanic with your own shop. You start off in what looks like your garage and then move on to bigger places as you get more money and more customers.GameplayIt handles nicely, sometimes the controls can be a bit bulky. You get a car, the customer tells you what is broken or what he thinks is broken and then you fix it. The way you do that is by examining parts and determining which ones need replacing or servicing. You can do all kinds of tests to see how the suspension is, how the engine is, how the tyres are and so on. You can change just about any part of the car and engine.You can even drive the cars on a closed course to check brakes and stuff, but the handling is really poor, almost farm simluator poor. And even though let's say the brakes are almost non existent when you checked, it brakes fine on the driving course, same with traction and speed, it's always the same no matter how broken the car is.You can magically reach into the car after removing some parts that are in the way, so you can after removing a lot of stuff for example change the flywheel or gearbox even. You would think that it will get repetitive after a while but as you progress further into the game you are completely on your own in trying to find what the problem is, you might only know that "when I accelerate there is a clunking sound from the eninge" or something. You can also tune cars and try to make them go faster on a dragstrip, I have not fully understood how to do this, I don't really have the know how on how to make a car faster, but not too fast.GraphicsThe graphics are really nice, way better than I expected. The cars are well modeled, so are all the parts. One thing that bugs me is that the cars look way too nice for some customers, there was one guy who had just bought a car for like 200€ and it wouldn't start, but it still looked really new out of the factory and recently waxed, you would expect it to be old and dirty.SoundThere is a radio which you can turn on and off for music, no real masterpiece music, just some generic simulator music, still good to listen too while working on cars. The sound the tools and engines make seem pretty realistic.Prize/RatingIf you are a fan of simulators and you are interested in how cars work this is the game for you. It's almost like a puzzle solving game once you progress a bit into it aswell, so if you are into that I would also recommend it.It is correctly prized, almost a bit too cheap even.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												Dumb. As an actual mechanic, i expected it to be far less complex than car repair actually is... but i never imagined it being this bad. The job where you have to do an obd scan on the car, i thought alright lets see whats wrong going on......doesnt even give errors or any info, scan complete, job done, same money as replacing a starter? Taking the intake mainfold off is just one click, but i have to wrench 4 bolts out of the airbox? Able to remove the fuel filter, which was located betweeen the fuel tank and body of the car, without removing the tank?I realize that if the game were too in depth it would be too hard and boring for most people. But i think a happy medium is needed and this is far from it. Neglects to mention simple things that people should know like lug pattern tightening. Guy says needs air, oil, fuel filter changes... changing the oil filter but not the oil? When you need new parts for a car, no looking up making sure you get the right parts, all parts fit every single car. Spare parts laying around fit every car. Hit it with a hammer, brand new again.I paid $1.69 for this game and im not even gonna request a refund since i got 54 minutes time waste outta it. Still i dont think its worth paying money to play. In fact even if they offered me money to play it i would still probably decline.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I should start by saying that....after putting over 100 hours of "gameplay" into working on my actual car (94 chevy caprice wagon...a land yacht of a wagon with a corvette motor :D )  this car mechanic simulator will not turn you into a mr. goodwrench!!With that being said though, it can be rather enjoyable, especially if you're someone who likes solving puzzles or diagnosing things (which is definitely up my alley!)...Despite it's enjoyability, I have to give a warning to newcomers....this simulator does very much indeed expect you to know generally where to find specidic parts, and to an extent, know what it does in order to diagnose the problem. Frankly, if you're one of those kind of people who have never seen the engine bay of your car (which is perfectly ok!)...chances are you won't find this very interesting in the least bit. Ultimately...this is more or less a "diagnostic simulator" more than a car mechanic simulator.,,knowledge of a parts' function will prove invaluable!Another thing to note, the english translation is (though mostly understandable) a smidge sloppy......so occasionally you'll get a problem to diagnose that can be a little....misleading, if you will...nothing too bad though.The graphics, I have to say, is definitely one of it's strong points.....honestly one of the best looking simulators I've seen as of late. I must also note the soundtrack.....though it may not be everyone's cup of tea, I find it pretty enjoyable, and it's long enough to where I didn't seem to find it too repetitive, even after 5 hours straight of playing.....and if you're wondering, it's primarily DnB and Dubstep.Overall, if you're a car guy or gal, and you at least somewhat know your way around an engine and drivetrain...this might prove pretty enjoyable.If chilling out in your garage wrenching on your car for an evening is something that you'd willingly do...this might prove pretty enjoyable.If you're looking for a software that will turn you into a legitimate mechanic,,,you should probably look elsewhere.If you're someone like a very special lady of mine, who is totally loveable and extraordinarily smart in certain aspects of life but couldn't identify a starter from an alternator.....you should probably look elsewhere, lol

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Awesome game, get it while it is on sale. I have learned alot about cars, was up till 6am playing.EDIT: After reading the other reviews I just had to stand up and defend this game. Let me start by saying that I know almost NOTHING about cars. The learning curve is not that steep. The missions slowly step you up to higher levels of knowledge. I only "almost" got stuck once. Now they added a resart mission button though. There IS 4X4 and V6. Now I want it to be MORE complex. I have learned alot. After a repair sometimes I wikipedia the parts I replaced and as a result my knowledge has gone up. To sum it up, yes this game has flaws, and the comments from the makers have bad grammer, but at $15 you really cant lose if you are interested in cars. If you went to the movies you'd spend the same amount and that experience only lasts 2 hours at most. "Skip the Big Mac and buy the game"

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Well, for starters, this concept is great, but it's kind of wierd & makes no sence most of the time.I've some basic knowledge of cars & some stuff is just out there. For example, to remove the starter you have to take it looking in from the hood, behind the motor. No way you would do that in real life when it's accessible from below and no way you'll get your face, hand and a tool down there from above. Second, to remove the power steering you'll have to remove BOTH Tie Rods from both sides, which also makes no sense. But to sum it up, it's a nice concept, fun to play for a couple of hours, but then you've done everything a couple of times. And besides, it isn't as "Gearhead garage" was. You aren't able to buy & mod your own cars.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
Per la versione italiana scorrete sotto!Premise: Don't look at my gameplay hours, I had the DRM free versione and imported the savegame.Car Mechanical Simulator 2014 is one of the few game in the Simulator jungle that keeps his head up without looking like a 2 cent program made to lure people.Gameplay:You are a mechanic and in the story mode you will start in your little workshop. You will receive orders from the costumers and you will have to find the problem by investigating and/or disassembling the car, then fix it..At start you can only do a little test run with the car (other than disassembling it piece after piece), then you will unlock the diagnostic center and the chiptuning.The structure of the mechanical parts is a good compromise between detailed and "Let's not freak out who doesn't do this job", the only flaw: Almost nothing change between different cars model.Game engine:Do not expect too much from that, it's not made to amaze you. It has a simple graphic, you will never see your character, when driving a car it feels really "arcade". Music and sound are minimal as well.Conclusion:Even if it's a little repetitive and I hated the quarter mile addon (the 2 DLC are included in the steam version) I suggest you to buy it even if you are slightly interested in the subject. It's well done without being too demanding and it's quite cheap (even better when discounted)---------------------------------------Premessa: Non guardate le mie ore di gioco, lo avevo come DRM free e ho importato i salvataggi.Car Mechanical Simulator 2014 è uno dei pochi titoli nella giungla dei Simulator che esce a testa alta senza sembrare un brutto programma creato solo per intortare i fessacchiotti.Gameplay:Voi siete un meccanico e nella modalità storia inizierete in una modesta officina. Riceverete vari ordini dai clienti e smontando e/o investigando dovrete trovare la fonte del problema e ripararla.All'inizio potrete fare solo un test a parco chiuso della macchina (oltre al controllarla smontando pezzo per pezzo), poi man mano che andrete avanti sbloccherete il test diagnostico in officina e il chiptuning.La struttura delle parti meccaniche è un buon compromesso tra dettagliato e "non spaventiamo chi non ne sa nulla", unico neo: Non cambia quasi nulla tra i vari modelli di auto.Parte tecnica:Qui non aspettatevi molto, non è fatto per stupire. Ha una grafica semplice, non vedrete il vostro personaggio, il movimento delle macchine è molto "arcade". La musica e il sonoro sono anch'essi minimali.Conclusione:Nonostante sia un po' ripetitivo e pur avendo odiato l'addon del quarto di miglio (i 2 DLC sono compresi nella versione steam) vi consiglio di prenderlo se siete anche solo un minimo interessati alla tematica. E' fatto bene senza risultare pesante ed è anche abbastanza longevo, inoltre non costa molto (ancora meglio se lo trovate in sconto)

content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Dont expect to be able to repair your own car in real life after playing this simulator. It has all of the essential parts of the car but it doesnt go into every tiny detail which you need to know in real life. An example of this is that you get to replace the brake pads and caliper but the brake lines are non-existent in the game. This is still a very good program for anyone to get themselves familiar with all the major car parts. At least next time you have your car tested and it fails, you know which parts are being replaced. For the price, this sim is cheaper than most books you can buy. You can visually learn where all major parts are without having to jack your own car up and asking someone else to teach you which is which. Its very easy to navigate too. 8.5/10

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												If you like to work on cars and you like puzzle games this IS for you.  If you know nothing about the basics of how a car is assembled but like puzzle games this might not be for you.  For instance, if you don't already know that a fuel pump is installed in the gas tank and the filter is in-line with that pump then you will be searching for days where to find a part that is supposed to be replaced.This game will not teach you how to fix a car. However, it can give you some basic ideas into what makes a car tick as well as learning some terminoligy such as what a tie rod actually is and where you would find it on a common car.  If your a mechanic (like me) it can be a little frustrating at times when you know what needs to be replaced and it makes you go through a ton of unneeded steps to make that replacement. But again, it is a puzzle game more than how a person would really work on a car.Some things that could be added to the tutorial IMHO would be to show that you can go to the repair bench and fix some of the parts rather than buying new...I'd also like to see controller support...WSAD in the test driving portions can make you sea sick.Lastly, the graphic optimizations need some work. I play this on an 27" iMac; I had to turn a lot of the options off to make it playable as well as reducing the resolution.  When I play it on my MacBook Pro on Windows7 I dont have to...even though my iMac has much better specs.All that said, I am very happy with this game and look forward to the new update.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Hey guys,I have 5 hours or so on the clock for this droll lil game called Car Mechanic Sim! I personally know next to nothing about cars, and while awaiting Dragon Age's impending release, I needed to kill a few hours and I thought I'd learn a lot from the game.What I got out of it:* I know a LOT more about car parts and their location.* I have a basic grasp of replacing car parts.* I got more enthusiastic about cars.* I had a fair amount of fun for a few hours.What I did not get out of it:* An intuitive interface (it's quite cumbersome and the camera is dreadful).* Knowing how to tell when a part is bad.* Learning what different parts do.* Really finding out  how to do it (the game has a necessary level of superficiality).All-in-all not a terrific or extremely realistic simulation, with actually pretty poor controls and very little in the sense of helpful tips or tutorials, but for the few bucks I spent on it, I do feel I learned a lot of useful things and I had fun learning them!

content:

												This is a very strange zen-like game. I'm not a car owner, nor have I ever driven one. I'm learning a lot about cars this way, in a simple and accessible way. Not to mention fun. Well, actually, fun might not be the best word. It is fun, but not like most games. I'm sure it's all simplified and not a simulator per se (I wouldn't dare ride a car where everything is held together by just a few bolts) but it's a neat little puzzle every time. Nice game for a nice price. Not for everyone, but nice to sink into and chill out working on cars.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												Car Mechanic Simulator isn't really a simulator. It teaches you about the very basics of what a car might consist of and then asks you to take out all the red parts and replace 'm with green parts. The 'diagnostic' tools at your disposal turn the objects of the car into a particular colour so that you can easily hunt down the red parts.There is no real problem solving involved, the diagnostics are always the same and some of them do not even require any interaction. The only difference is the outcome of what parts will be green, what parts will be yellow and what parts will be red. Occasionally you'll be asked to give an oil change, which is sort of a mini-game but not a very fun one.It is interesting to see what a car is made up of when you don't know (the first few missions were quite a learning experience for me) but after that the game drags on and on, giving you the same type of tasks over and over. You could finish all of these "objectives" a heartbeat if you didn't have to unscrew everything at a snail's pace and be forced to wait for it to be done loading when you switch "rooms" in your garage. I also saw no point to using second hand parts or trying to cheat customers out of money by swapping parts around, the game would never allow for it. So not only is there no real car problem diagnostics, you're not allowed to run the business your way and the information you receive on what the various parts actually do is meager to non-existent. in other words: this is not a simulator. Don't go in thinking you'll be able to fix your own car afterwards. You -might- be able to tell where the fuel filter is and what a serpentine belt looks like, though. I could neither recommend nor disrecommend this game, it is an interesting concept but I wish it was more of a learning experience. I am, however, leaning towards "yes" as I got my money's worth out of it (€ 1.50).The 1/4th Mile add-on is horrible, it crashed on me and it is only about driving in a straight line. The car store functions as a sort of power-up marketplace now instead.The 4x4 simply adds, you guessed it, off-road vehicles to the rotation.

You will start replacing/changing the same parts of a car, but this time you will like the best quality and functioning a car can give you by adding the best parts, this is known and tunning and isn't hard, only you just have to be interest in it, and see the awesome things you can make. One of the best programs ever done. That's it! Thanks to the developers.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												For the first couple fo hours playing the movement of the camera actually caused vertigo. By slowing it down I was able to begin t enjoy this game it IS a modern update of Gearhead Garage but without the ability to buy cars to fix up and sell. You start out in this great one car greasy little garage that fits like old jeans, and after doing innumerable repair jobs you transition to this beautiful spotless three car garage whose floor you could lick. No warning no congratulations, just boom, you're there. I find the game terribly lacking in direction or helping anyone who doesn't know much about cars. You're on your own pal. No tips, suggestions, arrows, manuals you can check, nothing I found. I also wish it offered more advanced repairs like total engine repairs not just sub-assemblies. The game is a good start but needs a lot of improvement. More variety of cars and parts, American cars, hints and tips. It's a good time for $10 but mybe the future holds improvements. Thanks for reading.

We've Been Waiting For Something Like That For A Long Time and Here It is.This game is great for anyone who likes working on cars (Duh its in the name.)The realism is a little off example you can run a car into the test track wall at 100+ Km/h and not get a penality for that action you did, You have to buy new rims each time you change a clients tires! Why couldn't you just buy the tire and then place it on the rim you already have? Like I said the realism is a little off. But for the most part the game is really good, The sounds of the cars is pretty good and the with over 150 parts to repair/replace you will get the feeling of a Car Mechanic.This game will need a decently good computer to run on good settings.PS: This game as a sequal coming out around April or July 2015 so be on the look out for that.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												Some people may remember a gem of PC gaming history called Gearhead Garage.  This is basically that game, but much, much better.And I have to give Gearhead Garage props, that game sucked me in for hours when I was younger.  It was incredibly simple, and can probably be easily converted to a flash game at this point.So you can imagine my elation when I saw this game.  Since it was indie, I didn't want to pay full price.  I've been burned by too many boring, broken, or incomplete indie games in the past on Steam.  I can say, knowing what I know now, I would definitely pay full price for it.At this point I am addicted to it.  For me, that is being stuck at work, and looking forward to getting home and playing th is game to unwind.  I usually play for an hour or so at a time (I'm a casual gamer).  That's pretty rare for me, only other games to do this are bigger hits like GTA V or The Last of Us.I'm a huge car nut, so I very much enjoy this game.  I've tinkered in real life.  Granted, the game completely simplifies all the repairs, but it's still satisfying and doesn't feel mundane or boring.I also really like the fact that you can "learn" things such as increasing profits, reducing parts prices in the catalog, or increasing the speed of removing bolts.Each scenario feels like a puzzle, and a few times I've been stumped and had to look something up online.  If you have any automotive experience, some of the jobs are easier for you to tackle, since you've probably experienced it in real life; e.g. tires are wearing out fast (suspension), car shuts of randomly (fuel pump), etc.  If you don't have experience, you will probably learn a thing or two, that is pretty cool.As far as graphics/sound/controls.  The graphics seem slightly unoptimized, FPS can dip down once you're in the shop, but the graphics don't look incredibly detailed.  Sounds are average, nothing amazing there.  Controls aren't too bad, the camera can be annoying sometimes with how it zooms.  But after a while you'll get to a point where you're flying through all the interactions and whatnot, so it's easy to get the hang and feel of.If you're a car nut like me, and have actually worked on cars before, this can be a fun romp for you.  I'd definitely recommend trying this game out, it is well polished, and well executed.  Big kudos to the developers!

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												I bought this game in a steam sale a while back but never had a chance to play it. Now that I have had a chance, I'm going to not recommend it to friends.The gameplay is simple and easy enough to follow for any mechanic enthusiast or hobbyist, and it is fun. Those are the pros.The cons however are that this game does not support "Windowed Fullscreen" mode, which is something 99% of games today have. On top of this, when fullscreened the game does not block your cursor from leaving the game window area which causes the game to minimize constantly if you have a setup with more than one monitor. The windowed mode doesn't minimize, but the game locks up.If these issues are resolved, I'll likely change my stance as the bits of the game I could play without it minimizing every 2 minutes were nice. However if you have more than one monitor, you'll need to give this one a pass.tl;dr1/5, gameplay was nice, but terrible programming and lack to common features in most modern games make it unplayable.

Posted: April 26, 2014
												Well, being a real life mechanic I don't even know where to start with how frustrating this game is at times. But I'll just say I can tell whoever designed the vehicles has never touched a wrench, and decided against having someone who is a Mechanic or at least mechanicly inclined to assist in even naming parts, yet alone on how some parts come off the vehicle. I have to remove the rear differential to remove the drive shaft? Uh, no. And 90% of theparts you have to access from the wheel well can be accessed from under the vehicle, without even removing the wheels.All in all, I actually would recommend this game amazingly, but that's because it's still a work in progress and has time to improve. Only advice is don't take mechanics lessons from it, you won't learn anything. And real mechanics beware, it'll drive you nuts.

												As someone training for a position as an auto insurance Claims Adjuster, this gave me an opportunity to learn about the workings of Auto Shops, cost of repairs, how repairs are done, and more without having to become too involved in actually doing this work, seeing as it is unnecessary for an office worker who merely needs the knowledge.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												VERY SUPRISED by how awesome this game is! Feels like a finished product for a change, not like other simulator games! Great sounds, great graphics, easy keyboard layout and generally fun to play, learning about different parts and problem finding. Starts off telling you how to move around and using the action key to interact with your environment, then it lets you do your own thing; completing jobs, buying books to learn more (to level up), test driving the cars etc. Levelling up through the game gives you bigger garages and better tools! Definitely worth the money and would recommend to anyone who loves cars and simulation games.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												Where to start.. As someone who used to do this for a living, this game could have had it's uses. Unfortunately it does not reflect any of the work a mechanic actually does, i understand that it can't be too complex but there are mountains of things missing from the actual cars, (water pump but no radiator, hoses heater core etc etc) inlet manifold comes off like it's a toy while the exhaust manifold uses 4 bolts per exhaust port  and bolts to the block not the head, wheel bearings, brake pipes, you name it. Silly stuff like making you remove the entire exhaust system from the back to let you remove the exhaust manifold. or the intake ducting and the air mass meter to be able to remove the airbox to change the filter i can only assume was done to make it drag out the career mode.Get someone who actually knows about cars to design the parts and it could have been goodEvery chassis is identical so it just turns into a grind.some of the explanations for the faults are complete gibberishCheck the oil for some reason becomes change ittelling you to change individual brake pads or do the discs but not the pads, changing oil without the filter and only individual spark plugs etc etc. This could get people thinking the real thing is a breeze and why you will find people doing a DIY port and polish job by tipping sand into the intake of their running engine...one to avoid IMO

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												DO NOT GET THIS GAME! I bought this thinking it would have some gameplay to it. It is the most shallow point and click adventure ever. Even if you are a car mechanic, do not get this! It will make you feel♥♥♥♥♥♥about your life. As soon as I started playing, it felt like I had wasted money, so I Alt+F4. I feel sick to the gut about how much money I wasted on a half finished, boring concept. Even if you have watched videos on this, and think it would be even the slightest bit fun, heed my warning.     My problem with this game is that it has 3 inches of gameplay. You get a car, you buy some parts, you take parts out, you put some in, then you assemble the vehichle. It's like a 3D jigsaw. What seperates this and a 3D jigsaw, though, is a 3D jigsaw does not guide your hand every step of the way! If the person giving you the car has not already told you what it is, then driving it once around a track or sitting in the car will tell you. I really hate this, as it removes any concept that this game once had. It drops from a puzzle with depth to a point and click. You get a lot of the same car in this game, and the cars aren't even real, so it's not like a lack of license.      The controls are clunky. The camera slides like it's on a demonic rail from hell sent to bite you in the f*cking♥♥♥♥♥♥ The mouse lags, and the head-sway would make you believe that you downed 3 bottles of painkillers before each job (I certainly thought about doing so). I understand that you can turn headsway off, but if you do that you feel like you have had a neck brace put on. The music is so loud and abrasive to my ears. It's not licensed, and I know that you can turn the music off, but that's boring. This game has NO middle ground!     I haven't even started on the mechanics. You can only access certain parts from certain angles. That part makes sense. My problem is that some parts make no sense as to where you extract them. You should take the gearbox out from the bottom, but no! You take it out through the top. Through the engine! Don't get me started on the nuts! You should unscrew nuts diagonally, but this doesn't matter, acoridng to Car Mechanic Simulator 2014. For a game specializing in CAR MECHANICS they don't know anything!     You can buy second hand parts from a dodgy website, but there is almost no point as you can either repair the parts, or buy them new. Second hand parts are never good enough. You could repair them, but that takes extra time, and it's a lot easier to just buy new ones.      To cleanse my ways, I am going to donate £13 worth of toys and stationary to the bravery box in a cancer ward. It's the only thing that my £13 could be spent on to justify spending so much on a game that made me feel sick. I do agree with funding indie developers, but only if they have good concepts. I was stupid to buy this in the first place. Learn from my mistake, or donate £13 to a teenage cancer trust. Your choice. http://www.clicsargent.org.uk/

												I find this game great, like what others have said, this game isnt in depth, its a very general game. The reason i'm giving this game a 4 out of 10, is because on many different occasions, the game tells me the order isn't complete. I've completed the order, replaced all the parts to green, yet the game still tells me i messed up. So, after many hours in this game trying to figure out what i did wrong, the conclusion is this: the game was wrong. I wouldn't pay full price for this game, i'm glad i got it on sale. One more thing, i can get motion sick in some games, this game is one of them. There is actually a setting that lets your character "bob" his head up and down. The windows in game shouldn't be bubbly, make the windows clear, i want to see the outside clearly, there are also little white dots floating around constantly in the game that serve no purpose.
