Posted: June 28, 2014
												Didn't expect much from this game at first and bought with the summer sale.  That being said I have enjoyed playing it while I work.  It does not have a lot of indepth gameplay.  I find it relaxing and more of a puzzle game than anything.  They're on the right track, reminds me of Farming Simulator.  I look foward to more development with future titles if they are able to make them.  At the moment I recommend buying the game if you can get it on sale. It is not worth spending over $10 bucks on it. But will fill your time nicely if you are looking for a change in your normal genre.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 starts off in a garage as you take on the role of the Mechanic. The goal is simple: perform the tasks on the work order using your trusty wrench and diagnostic tools (including test drives), not to mention your two eyes to find and repair the various parts and make a profit.The game itself isn't terrible, the graphics are quite good and the gameplay is fluid enough, but the repetition and free-roaming aspect of the game can become tedius if not completely irritating at times. To give an example of this, take a work order that simply says "The car pulls to the right sometimes." You'll find yourself pulling the car apart to find the problem, then you need to walk to the computer to buy the new part, walk back, put everything back together and move on. Sometimes the simplest problem becomes a headache because you have to remove several parts to get to the part you need to replace.Walking around the car and having to work on it section by section can be a bit of a pain, but for simulation sake is pretty accurate enough to real life that it makes sense. Although, in a gaming aspect can just be viewed as a bit of a waste of time and makes some jobs a bit too long to be enjoyable. The fact that you can't create and build your own cars and sell them off is a bit of a letdown as well.All-in-all, if you want to remove bolts and replace parts all day long, this is your game. I would recommend getting it at a discounted price if you can. Although a nice little past-time game, long-term and replayability is definitely not on the books for this title. The potential is there but unfortunately it falls just short of a good simulator.Rating: D+

Posted: April 5, 2014
												I'm on the border of recommend/not recommend for this game.This game is made only for a very select group - one that wants to learn all of the basic mechanical components of a vehicle, and to learn associated problems with parts.If you don't enjoy taking things apart, sometimes painstakingly, you won't enjoy this game. The jobs range from really easy to complex. Sometimes you have to take apart 5 parts just to get to one.For those that do enjoy the reconstruction aspects, it's a lot of fun. There are still a few flaws, IMO. One annoying thing is trying to figure out which side of the vehicle to approach a problem. Do I raise the car, or fix it from the hood? This can be annoying trying to figure out from which angle the game wants you to remove parts. Another annoying aspect is camera movement. There aren't enough variables to really move the point of view to where you want it. This makes things unnecessarily frustrating.Still, I recommend this game becaue it's a concept that's new, using a video game to actually learn car mechanics realistically! They could one day develop this more into becoming a full training tool for those of us unfortunate enough to not have a garage :-(

If you don't really know much about cars, you're not gonna know what to do. the game doesn't offer up much in hints if you get stuck, and it's not really the best in telling you exactly what it wants you to do. Posted: January 28, 2014
												This is a interesting game. It's not a shooter, a racer, a builder, a platform jumper. Instead, you repair cars. The game genre can be considered in the puzzle catagory, although these are not mind-bendingly difficult puzzles. It definitely would help if you know something about the inner workings of a car, however this isn't really necessary as it's possible to figure things out as you go along. The game consists of a number of scenarios or missions; in this game they are called "orders". You receive an order to fix a problem on a car. The description given to you may not be completely comprehensive or even clear; that is part of the puzzle. Your challenge is to diagnose the problem and figure out how to fix it. The graphical interface the player uses is mouse driven and is fairly straightforward and obvious. There are some peculiarities with the camera control; the camera is focused on an object and the player has to click on another object to move the focus. It's not really very difficult and most folks will figure out quickly and intuitively how to move the camera to the best position. There are a few minor bugs but the developer Red Dot has been very supportive in providing updates quickly; about a half dozen in the first three days the game has been available. There have been several fixes, but also some user enhancements and other tweaks to improve gameplay. This is most commendable compared to some other developers that push a game out the door and then disappear. It is hoped that Red Dot continues this excellent support and responsiveness.The game, not withstanding the few bugs, is in excellent shape. Few crashes have been reported and I don't believe I have seen a single mention of issues with different Windows versions. No guarantees are intended, just my opinion based on observation. Your experience may differ. The game, for being fairly simple in presentation, is graphically very nice. The videos and screenshots don't really capture how pretty the game is. Be sure to verify that your video card is up to the specs listed on the Store page. Having a video card myself that is on the lower end of the spec range, I am pleased that even though I have had to turn down all the video settings in the game to their minimums, the game still looks very nice and there is no detriment whatsoever in the gameplay.Another plus for this game is that it is something that adults can play with children; there is nothing shocking or disruptive and since almost the entire game is presented in visual rather than textual format, it would be easy for children to enjoy.This game is NOT recommended for those seeking a deeper, complex challenge. Those folks would probably find themselves bored and frustrated. Also, this game involves some amount of simple repetition; many of the "orders" (missions) involve removing and reinstalling the same parts the player has removed and reinstalled in other, previous missions. Some might find this aspects offputting, but for others this will be rather theraputic; there is a certain relaxation and comfort in the familiar.Overall I would recommend this game to others, with the caveat mentioned in the above paragraph about the difficulty of the challenge. I would compare this game to Euro Truck Simulator 2 or Farming Simulator 2013; it is not difficult to play, but can be rewarding, satifying and relaxing. And the price is very reasonable as well.

Posted: March 8, 2014
												though I recommend this game for general fun, it is not a true auto mechanic simulator nor should it be considered a learning tool for becoming one.  Their is no engine block disasembly or removal of pistons, crackshafts ect nor can you adjust the throttle.  The engines in all the cars are exactly the same, and if you work on a rear wheel drive car, the engine is mounted like a front wheel drive which is NOT how engines in RWD are monuted. The drive shaft comes out of seemingly nowhere and even if it's rear wheel drive the gear box has shoulders for a FWD.  The only engine configuration is the fuel injected I-4 and V 6 no uniquness or difficulty based on unfamiliarity, in fact, anyone can work on these cars, very basic stuff.  I took automotive service technology in vo-tech and know something about cars, this is totally inacurate.  However, I think there is a lot of BASIC stuff that can be learned from this game, as there is a lot of detail and work on suspension, though that is where it ends. No engine work some clutch assemblages to work on at times. The "test" driving is nothing of the knd, I never use it unless an order calls for it, the cars handle exactly the same whether you change out all the old parts for new or not. There is no performance gain in test driving.  Basically, you do a work order, then go to the next. There are three garages each more advanced than the last, however little difference besides a few diagnostic tools you rarely use anyway, most people just want there tires changed and their spark plugs replaced anyhow.  I like the game just to pass the time but there are more advanced games of this nature and it is not a true simulator.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												FIVE POINT SYSTEM REVIEW WARNING!!!* I've got a five point system review, in that it scores a point if it seems to achieve what it's going for, this is by no way, shape, or form good nor bad. It simply means, I personally felt that it achieved what it was going for and nothing more. Graphics, music/sound is self explanitory, Gameplay refers to controls and functionality. Genre refers to if it achieves it's actual Genre, if it's a simulation, did it achieve being that? Genre is broad, but can be fudged up by developers. Overall fun, refers to if I had fun or if maybe I think you'll have fun with this title. With that in mind, onto the review. *Graphics: 1 Point = Yes, graphics were decent, but could have been slightly better.Music/Sound: 1 Point = Yes, though the music could have added more tracks to seem less repititive.Gameplay: 1 Point = Functions well, felt very natural from the very start.Genre: 1 Point = Tis advertised as a Car Mechanic Simulator, and in many degrees it achieves such.Overall: 1 Point = It's very fun, HOWEVER, latter levels seem more of a chore.Total: 5/5My first impresions of the game were quite fond, everything was new, and I had to figure out, A) What was wrong with the car, and B) How to get it out, and replace it. For some levels, it took me a few trys, like figuring out where the spark plugs were and how to get to them. Mostly, it was pretty easy once you get the flow of things in the game. Replacing parts I've never replaced earlier felt exciting. Rear Axel here, 4 wheel drive there, replace muffler ect.It wasn't long before I mastered this game and quickly was gaining cash. It's here were fun started to turn into a bit of a chore. Everything was too easy towards the latter levels of the game. I knew how to do everything and beat all 75 levels within 2 days. I even replaced one cars whole parts just to stop the game from being mundane. To say there isn't enough to do is an understatement, while the early stages are fun, there really isn't much stopping you from plowing through this game. Latter stages are repitive, but are still fun in their own right.I'd still recommend this title, and see that it has potential, however, I think you should wait till the DLC and content updates come for this game before buying. It's a good game, just not as good as you may hope.

												To use the word simulator for this game is spot on.  There are no hints to tell you where the parts are, as you should know if you are a car junky!You can test drive the cars and the spacebar is an unlisted button that you can use to use the handbrake of the car during test drives.A must have for car lovers.Bad points:- The camera view controls are a bit tricky, not only you must rotate them but you should click on the part you want to focus on while you rotate.- Adding on, big/long parts like the exhaust will center on itself even when you are unbolting the bolts at the end, so the camera will not focus on the bolts and it can get out of view..- I do wish there were bikes too..- There should be opening hours, so that there is a better and more realistic feel of a workshop./

Posted: February 11, 2014
												This game is NOT like Gear Head Garage if anyone reamembers that game. But it is a lot of fun. But it does certainly has room for improvement. But I higlhly recommend playing the DEMO first before blindly purchasing it based on players reviews. I sort went into this game thinking cool another Gear Head Garage game, but sadly it is not that in any shape or form. First off you are given jobs, and given a certain amount of how much the job cost. It is up to you to pin point the problem based on what the customer said or by test driving, or doing a test tech in bigger garages. One thing I learned while playing is the vehicle will have a lot of red parts, but you won't have enough money to buy/fix them all, just buy/fix what the person wanted and send it on its way. Buying/Fixing the red parts will put your shop in a early grave, so while tempting. Just DON'T do it.One job that really threw people off was the fuel filter job. While having replaced the fuel filter in my car recently. I knew it was in or near the gas tank, so I went there right away. But other's stumbled on this job for a long time. Now I said this game has much needed improvements.Like jobs, they need to be rewarding or graded on how well you did also if you missed something major. They should of done a story line or something to make the game interesting, but there really isn't any voices. And if you shut music off it's really really really quiet. Other than the occasional sound of the nuts coming offAlso the ability to just build a vehicle from the ground up and they paint it cool and sell it. While this isn't technically what mechanic does, this game based on the jobs, isn't technically what a mechanic does either, I never been to a shop where the customer pays for the job first, unless it's routine maintenance.  With that being said it should have the option of adding parts in case there is a bigger problem than originially thought.Also there needs to be more parts. Able to fix more parts. More second hand parts,, in much better condition. Since most of those parts are bit of a rip off.  Also the parts cost a lot. I mean A LOT. Oil Filter costing 50 bucks.The camera angle is something to be desired. especially in the back of the vehicle. I had a hard time viewing the vehicle. Sometimes the WASD buttons would reverse. How do you get to bigger badder garages, by doing jobs, that is how. I am not sure how long I played but didn't seem like very long and I got my 2nd garage pretty fast. Changing oil is pretty routine. But changing oil in the 2nd garage is odd. You have put it in this catch oil pan and you have be very percise where it is or you lose 100 dollars. The first garage wasn't like that you just drained the oil and that was that. Just seems to be a step back, instead of a step forward. And in the 2nd garage for sure, why can't you now fix tires? One of the tires in the game cost either 1600 or 1700 for one tire, I could see if it was all 4 tires. But this is just one tire. Jobs don't pay a lot, so replcaining one tire is really expensive. On the plus side of things there is going to be FREE DLC. So perhaps some improvements in game play as well more things to do. While I do reommend this game. I really recommend playing the DEMO first. Here is hoping the Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is taking the ideas of the fans and making EVEN better than the original.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												Well. What can I say??I've been wanting to play this for a little while, and I've now managed to have a little blat..First impressions? Well, as a mechanic by trade, I really wish it were that easy to remove bolts... But that's not the name of the game here is it? Granted the tutorial is 30 seconds long, but that, to me, sort of adds appeal, as it means you have to think about what you're doing. This isn't a mindless shoot em up. You have to think logically, especially when it starts getting into replacing a clutch and so on.What needs to come off first before I can get to the real issue. Pretty much like a normal car. As a really nice touch, I like the fact you get money returned for recycling!! Granted, there's not much variation in the vehicles, like RWD, 4x4 etc, which would add more dimention to the game, but as it is, is has what a good majority of cars now are. Front Wheel Drive.I'd like to see more parts to be added, and get down to the real nitty gritty parts, like circlips and split pins, you know, all the little fiddly bits, or even having a seized stud which you've got to use oxy-acetylene to warm up to get out, even a snapped bolt..Maybe I'm being too traditional there, but these things happen!!One thing that IS missing.. Girly calenders. Sorry for being sexist here ladies. I have yet to come across a garage that doesn't have a girly calender somewhere. And who in the world had an FSO Polonez poster on the wall?? hehehe! (1st garage, behind the lift control) Yes, I know RedDot are a Polish company before you start!Ah! another good point.. A PROPER lift would be advantagous here. One where you specify the height or at least have complete free wheeling, instead of using a scissor jack??  Do garages really have lifts like these now? Be nice if the lifts were the double poster type, just so you could work at the height you want, not either on the floor or in the air.Again, being picky because of grease monkey.. =)Overall, if you want to learn a little about cars and like a little challenge, then this game is ideal.To me, this is a fun game, not a sim, but I enjoy it enough to keep playing.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												This simulator sits on an odd waypoint; likely too difficult for those who know nothing about cars, but too easy for those who do. As a result the game quickly becomes a tedious follow through of removing bolts in to replace certain parts. The only real difficulty lies in establishing what the customer actually wants done sometimes.If you're looking for an updated version of Gearheads Garage, this aint it, thats for sure. The game could have done with perhaps trying to be more educational if they were targeting the non-mechanically minded. For example, instead of having someone remove a trailing rod, it'd have been clever to have a brief description available as to what this part does, symptoms of when its gone wrong and so on.As it stands, the cars all look the same, you're limited to just how much actual work you can do on a car and it lacks the realism of your typical garage in that you can't half♥♥♥♥♥a job then overcharge the customer.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												Brief: Gameplay: 8/10, Graphics: 8/10, Sound: 8/10 Replayability 5/10.In depth:As far as simulators go, this is a very good one. Graphics are great especially the wireframe view, and the controls are fairly easy and intuitive. Sounds are pretty good also especially the main menu soundtrack. Going through career mode is enjoyable but I can't imagine myself playing it again for quite a while.As far as gameplay goes, it looks to be aimed at a fairly beginner mechanic to a hobbyist. If you know how to strip an engine down and rebuild it I probably wouldn't recommend it. I know the main concepts of how all the parts of an engine work, however I still learnt a bit from this game, and it is still keeping me entertained. There is a few annoying things (like having to remove the airpipe, then 4 bolts and the airflow meter, then another 4 bolts for the air filter cover, before being able to see the air filter) but this is minor.It starts off where all the engines are 4 cylinder front wheel drives, then after about 15 or so missions it slowly introduces you to more (4x4's, 6 cylinders) and it starts from basic problems "replace my brake pads" to "my boss told me to bring the car to you but i have no idea what you need to fix" type jobs. After playing about 40 missions, I'm still enjoying the game (especially the dyno-tuning mini-game) and i really hope they bring out a more detailed and more complex version next year. I'll definately buy it. I would like to see the ability to "hear" and "feel" problems (ie: when driving around the test track) or being able to negotiate my own price with the customer (maybe ringing them up halfway through a job saying "this is also broken, want it fixed?" or "i can do this cheaper if i use 2nd hand parts". I would also like to see more types of engines (maybe trucks, rear-mounted engines, motorbikes).All in all, its a good game, and i'm stopping this review now so i can go and play it more...

Posted: June 20, 2015
												This is an awesome beginning to what I hope will be come a long running series!A few things that you need to understand,1. There is only about 50% of the car to take apart when comparing it to a real car. The big pieces are there but not all the little ones 2014 focused on suspension, exhaust, and drivetrain.. However, for that 50% it is actually accurate on what is on the cars today. Thats why I hope they keep up with the series and by the end get full 100% accuracy and maybe even customizability of the cars.2. In this game its easy to learn about all the peices of your car while not getting covered in oil. It is very repetative but it is still pretty fun, and the best part is that you don't have to do it in person to learn about how to take your car apart. I have done this in real life, I own a jeep, it can get very dirty. So I highly recommend this game if you like those dinner dash kind of games and also to people who want to learn a little bit about how a car is put togething and what is under the hood as they say.The only cons to the game is I wish they would spend a little more time in updating or fixing the "running a garage" aspect of the game. However it is obvious that they are focusing on the "car and parts" aspect which I'm fine with too. Again, hopefully later in the series they will fix it.Best price, buy it if they have a kickstarter campagn! They had one for the new 2015 game and it was 10 bucks to buy in and get a copy and you know you are supporting the developers directly. The 2015 game will have a lot more detail, so far I noticed that they are focusing on the engine block (2014 focused on suspension, exhaust, and drivetrain.)

Posted: June 14, 2015
												Car Mechanic Simulator at its core is pretty simple, you point and click on the various parts of the car to remove/add them back on. After reviewing the invoices you can remove parts or order them from your computer. The directions on the invoices can be somewhat vauge at times and usually involves replacing parts you didn't need to. Overall I found it to be fun, if you go into it without a vast knowledge of cars it can be somewhat challenging, and there is definitely things you'll miss the first time around. (Example, I didn't know the garage had an oil pan and lost 100 dollars for oil cleanup.) I picked this up as part of the playway bundle for a dollar so I have no complaints, I've gotten my money's worth out of it, but your milage may vary.

Posted: January 7, 2016
												6/10I got the game after they freshly released it and always waited for their little DLCs they've released but the game has some serious issues that are annoying but not a real death sentence.Positive things:- The job variety is alright. In the story mode you dont have to do the same thing twice in a row, you get to see different approaches.- The graphics are "alright" for a studio like this.- Many parts to disassemble. Just had the fun on a mission to take a whole car apart and get it back together.- Tuning possible but very limited.- Car class variety from vans over sedans to sports cars.- Chance to order used parts and brush them up to save money.Negative aspects:- The tuning itself is set as a minigame that makes absolutely no sense. I am not a car mechanic, dont intent to become one but I cant imagine that you sit infront of a screen and move a damn flipchart of an EEPROM around until the percentage matches.- Very poor physics in the test drive. Every customer nearly needs the test drive to be sure that the car is working but like the game is made it just does not represent anything, the car feels like a fish in a god damn tank.- The DLCs dont really brought that much of content to be satisfied. - Credit is a one time thing in the whole game, seriously?- Double Monitor use always throws you out of the game when your mouse leaves the game, never have that happen in other games.- No customer wants to keep their car parts, makes the form and the difficult of the game pretty low.- The race track is just a horror with the physics as well.Potential that could have been used in my eyes but well...I still enjoyed it, nothing outstanding, can pay that low price for it.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												This is a interesting game. It's not a shooter, a racer, a builder, a platform jumper. Instead, you repair cars. The game genre can be considered in the puzzle catagory, although these are not mind-bendingly difficult puzzles. It definitely would help if you know something about the inner workings of a car, however this isn't really necessary as it's possible to figure things out as you go along. The game consists of a number of scenarios or missions; in this game they are called "orders". You receive an order to fix a problem on a car. The description given to you may not be completely comprehensive or even clear; that is part of the puzzle. Your challenge is to diagnose the problem and figure out how to fix it. The graphical interface the player uses is mouse driven and is fairly straightforward and obvious. There are some peculiarities with the camera control; the camera is focused on an object and the player has to click on another object to move the focus. It's not really very difficult and most folks will figure out quickly and intuitively how to move the camera to the best position. There are a few minor bugs but the developer Red Dot has been very supportive in providing updates quickly; about a half dozen in the first three days the game has been available. There have been several fixes, but also some user enhancements and other tweaks to improve gameplay. This is most commendable compared to some other developers that push a game out the door and then disappear. It is hoped that Red Dot continues this excellent support and responsiveness.The game, not withstanding the few bugs, is in excellent shape. Few crashes have been reported and I don't believe I have seen a single mention of issues with different Windows versions. No guarantees are intended, just my opinion based on observation. Your experience may differ. The game, for being fairly simple in presentation, is graphically very nice. The videos and screenshots don't really capture how pretty the game is. Be sure to verify that your video card is up to the specs listed on the Store page. Having a video card myself that is on the lower end of the spec range, I am pleased that even though I have had to turn down all the video settings in the game to their minimums, the game still looks very nice and there is no detriment whatsoever in the gameplay.Another plus for this game is that it is something that adults can play with children; there is nothing shocking or disruptive and since almost the entire game is presented in visual rather than textual format, it would be easy for children to enjoy.This game is NOT recommended for those seeking a deeper, complex challenge. Those folks would probably find themselves bored and frustrated. Also, this game involves some amount of simple repetition; many of the "orders" (missions) involve removing and reinstalling the same parts the player has removed and reinstalled in other, previous missions. Some might find this aspects offputting, but for others this will be rather theraputic; there is a certain relaxation and comfort in the familiar.Overall I would recommend this game to others, with the caveat mentioned in the above paragraph about the difficulty of the challenge. I would compare this game to Euro Truck Simulator 2 or Farming Simulator 2013; it is not difficult to play, but can be rewarding, satifying and relaxing. And the price is very reasonable as well.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												This was the first game I played that revolved around cars, and it's what inspired me to go take the air filter out of my car and learn more about mechanics! Posted: December 5, 2014
												First impressions were fair to good.  Graphics are reasonable and frame rate is good on my rig.The controls, particularly for the camera, are a little quirky.  Using WASD to manipulate the camera isn't ideal really in my opinion, the mouse is more appropriate for that function.As you would expect from a budget title, the game lacks depth.  I found I was really quite bored after an hour.  Endless unbolting of parts, which, whilst realistic, becomes very tiresome.  The vast majority of jobs you receive are simplistic and in all honesty, even with my limited knowledge of car mechanics, there was no real puzzle here.  There is no "businesss simulation" either.  A single click awards you with a one time bank loan.  That is about the only business decision you make.You can purchase upgrades which improve the speed at which you remove bolts, or a percentage increase in income per jobs, but there are few options besides this.Test driving the cars is exactly the same each time and even on repairs you would expected to hear an indication of a fault, such as a work order describing knocking from the suspension, I heard nothing.I found the gameplay very repetitive indeed.  There is not much to recommend here I'm afraid.  It might keep a younger person occupied for a few hours but thats about it.  Educational value is minimal beyond explaining the names of car parts and their rough locations although even these are only accurate on a very basic level.Cannot really recommend this title, it is just too lacking to be called a simulator.  Buy a meccano set instead.

Posted: December 5, 2014
												Superb game, the graphics are decent, I enjoyed the attention to small details such has dirt or rust on some parts, the realism of the damaged parts sounds on the test track, the variance in the contracts, the oil color depending on its usage, the music and finally the variance in cars. There were a few things that could be tweaked and added. First the camera is good but needs a little tweaking when reaching its angle limits. What could be added is random generate id codes for each parts. Why ? well for the fun of it, in one of the contracts, I fixed a water pump and bought one but could not know which was which (not a big issue but would add a little feature). Another thing that could be added is part sorting, this would greatly help. Finally, it would be great to go play in the pistons, camshafts and crankshaft.My final score 9/10 Worth the purchase

Posted: December 6, 2014
												The problem with CAR MECHANIC SIMULATOR 2014 is the interface.  Even at the lowest settings (and you will want to set mouse moves to the lowest setting) the controls are mushy and awkward.  The main problem is the constant need to center the screen on what you are aiming for, rather than just using the mouse to point at it.  Also, too many things involve clumsy menus and mouse moves where keyboard shortcuts would work a lot better.The general gameplay elements are good, and I think the game would be enjoyable if the controls didn't make every simple task a chore and a nuisance.  It reminds me trying to accomplish anything in SURGEON SIMULATOR.  I have not tried other games in the "Simulator 2014" set, but if they share this interface, I won't be playing them.  I cannot recommend this game.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												I played a version of this game many many many  years (over a decade ) ago. It's pretty much the same except now there are work orders,a test drive section, a parts ordering mechanism,and a radio. Overall it's the same game. (but it was on sale for less than 3 bucks so what the hell I picked it up).Let me say this, as a simulator this game falls wayyyy short, I've never done a brake job that didn;t have caliper bracket bolts or a bracket for that matter so yeah not too realilistic there. The prices are very odd, there's no pressing out bearings (so far anyway) and one of the first 5 jobs i was supposed to test an alternator...well when I removed the thing it said 6% cheapest option was replacement, ordered part put it on, got the belt on, took the battery out (1%) cheapest option was repair (90 some dollars....what shop doesn't have a charger to  "repair" a battery for free?) put it all together went to close out the repair and low and behold it said to test alternator...what the ♥♥♥♥ does it matter now that i replaced it? and it wouldn't let me just check the condition of the old alternator... so ♥♥♥♥ that.Other things to note; the mouse is laggy in game, it has different speeds in different parts of the game i.e the menu, the game, the computer ordering , all different speeds incredibly frustrating. The test drive section is pretty pointless, I don't think I know of a single person who would want me to put their car through such strain after fixing it and it's clunky.In summary if you have an interest in working on cars but no knowledge this game is actually a decent tool to familiarize yourself with the components of the average automobile, the version I played so long ago went a long way in helping me memorize the main engine components of the average v8 of the era and this game is more advaned. But you're better off just working on cars to learn how. so yeah don't buy this unless it's super cheap and you have next to 0 car knowledge.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												As a car enthusiast, I found the game to be overly simplified. The interface exaggerates the monotonous aspects of working on cars, while skipping entirely the actual difficulties and triumphs. The main workflow consists of getting a car with a job sheet. The sheet has a vague problem and a dollar amount you'll be paid if you fix the problem. The first assumption made here is that the person who wrote the job sheet knew what the problem was but failed to tell you. They also figured out how much it would cost for you to fix the problem and are charging the car owner that amount. If you fix exactly the problem, you will be profitable. This is a very flawed model since it gives no penalty for diagnosis. You can tear the entire car apart, find the item that has the most amount of wear, if that item can be replaced or repaired for the amount on the job sheet, then it's likely your problem. Rarely, the problem can be 2 or more parts that are marginal.There are several "makes" of car in this game, and several different configurations. Most cars and minivans are 4 cylinder, front wheel drive, suv's are all wheel drive, and a few performance cars are v6 (LOL) with rear wheel drive. All cars share most of the same parts. A front strut for the suv fits the economy car, performance car, minivan, everything. There is no confusion about parts at all. The air filter fits everything, as does exhaust pipes, mufflers, cats, brake calipers, brake shoes, end links, shocks, struts, fuel pump, fuel filter, spark plugs, ignition modules, and about a dozen other parts.The mechanics of the game are tedious. You get your car and job sheet. You have to figure out which part to replace, but some of the parts you cannot diagnose till you've taken other parts off. For example, if you want to diagnose any suspension component, you have to remove the wheel before you can diagnose anything else. Once the wheel is removed, you can diagnose a layer of components. Diagnosis consists of either selecting diagnose mode, and clicking on the part, or removing the part. Diagnosing the part makes it turn a color from green to red, with green being the 100% effective and red being 1% effective. It appears that anything below 30% is your bad part, with 17% being the most common threshold for failed part. Remove the part, go to the computer and buy another part, sell the bad part on the used part market, and then install the new part. Put everything back together again. Get paid, rinse, repeat till you're sick of it, which for me was about 2 weeks. One area in particular that bugs me is the brake caliper removal sequence. I have removed brake calipers many times, from many different cars, trucks and motorcycles. in every case, the brake pads stayed in the caliper when I removed the caliper. The game has the brake pads stuck to the rotors, so an additional step is needed to remove the pads. The problems encountered are textbook, and the solutions are also textbook. Anyone who knows about fixing cars will know immediately what the problem is when reading the job sheet. Could this 'game' be used to gain experience in fixing cars... maybe. One would understand more fully what each component was and how it fits into the whole, and how it's failure would impact the whole. The part about the actual work, I believe would only help someone by giving them a general idea of where on a car that item lives. The work portion is so over simplified as to be a great source of laughs for the first 100 times, then tedious boredom after that. There is no searching for the correct sized socket, then discovering you need the deep wall, and don't have one in that size, or picking the wrong size, and rounding off the bolt, so now you have to use a pipe wrench and buy a new bolt... or discovering you cannot fit your hand into the space provided so you make an elaborate contraption of extensions and universal joints only to discover you didn't need to take that bolt out after all. There's nothing about anti-seize, lock-tite, assembly lube, torque wrenches, impact wrenches, nothing at all about tools. I never had to dig out the welder, sawzall, hammer, prybar, gloves or safety glasses during the game, which makes it totally unrealistic. None of the bolts are ever stuck, rusted, or broken. They're always easy to remove, and install. I never burned my hand on a hot exhaust, or got shocked by a faulty spark plug wire, or got battery acid on my good jeans, or spilled oil all over the engine and had a smoke bomb when the car was started. Also, you cannot install parts out of sequence, so the all too common scenario of discovering you forgot to install the wheel bearing seal after you finished putting everything back together never happens. I cannot really imagine an audience for this game. Maybe servicemen overseas who miss working on their cars, or prison inmates... A teenager should have their own jalopy to work on and learn from. An adult inclined toward this will have a project car to work on, and certainly will be working on it instead of pretending to work on it with this game. Someone who is considering this line of work as a vocation won't get an accurate picture with this sim, but will get a very general idea of the workflow. Guys like me see this as a novelty and buy it to be disappointed. Perhaps someone with less hands on experience would benefit, or enjoy the simulation. The design and artwork for the sim is good. I will recommend this sim/game for people curious about working on cars. If you already know how to work on cars, pass on this.

Posted: February 19, 2014
												Car Mechanic Simulator 2014, where gaming titles are concerned, sounds about as boring as watching paint dry but the game is actually quite fun and enjoyable. You dont have to be an expert in the field of automotive maintenance to quickly get a feel for the game either.You start out in a run down small neighborhood garage, a car will be brought in, a clip board with a complaint or two from the vehicles owner will be written, and tasks you need to perform to get paid for the job will be listed. It can be as easy as a quick oil and filter change to something as complex as changing out a 4 wheel drive transmission or having to inspect numerous parts of the car for defects chasing down an elusive "squeek" or "squeel". You can repair parts, replace parts, test drive the vehicle to help in your diagnostic... and as your experience and skills develop you can even chip tune vehicles.As the game progresses, you move up to bigger and better garages and begin receiving higher end automobiles from clients, There are some management aspects to the game as well... as in real life parts can be expensive, you might have to scavenge used parts, or repair existing parts to save money while meeting the customer's needs. Additionally, each job is worth a total cash value, if you get too carried away or start repairing every little minor thing on the car you could end up spending $1,500 bucks out of your own pocket to complete a job worth $1,000 so certain repair vs replace aspects have to be kept in mind.This is not going to be one of those games that keeps you on the hook for months on end like some fast paced shoot em up might... however, I am well into repairing my 50th vehicle and have spent nearly 10 hours playing the game over the last few days as i write this review and i still want to play more, and with the potential for add ons and expansions, the entertainment value is certainly there.PROS: low learning curve, easy to use, straight forward interface, excellent graphicsCONS: camera movement and clicking icons can feel a bit clunky but it is not really a major distractionWhere i would like to see this title go: supposedly there is a 4x4 Offroad edition in the works. But i think a great direction to take this game would be an expansion for off-road and sporting and performance accessories. in other words a customer comes in not with problems, but wants to have a high performance exhaust and a supercharger installed. Or another customer wants his truck to have a roll bar, off road lights and a lift kit installed or any number of countless modifications. Additionally, i think an expansion for aircraft maintenance would be a great addition... periodic inspections of the airframe and powerplant, overhaul of engines and components, repairs etc.In the end, Car Mechanic Simulator is a fun title, and a great way to learn a few of the basics of how cars work if you dont have much of an understanding of cars, and it is a great way to kill time if you are a tinkering type

Posted: July 13, 2014
												So this game is sort of a neat premise with not enough effort put into its execution. It is, as many have already pointed out, somewhat limited in scope. You click to unscrew bolts, you inspect the condition of the parts, you order new ones from the computer and you replace the old ones. Done. Occasionally you test-drive the cars on this one small ugly test course. So far, the insides of most cars I have repaied looked the same! If you get to work on a muscle car then the setup does change, but basically the insides only differ per type of car and not per car. All the major parts of a car are there but don't expect to be replacing some small stressed screw somehwere or repairing a crack in the windshield. This game does not go that deep.But since I know almost nothing about cars, it did teach me a thing or two about them so mission accomplished I guess.I recommend it but only if it's on sale. 20 euros is a bit too steep. The only thing this game really has going for it is its uniqueness, which is a shame because I think an in-dept car mechanic simulator would be an interesting game.

Posted: July 10, 2014
												For a game that calls itself a "simulator," there are several aspects of this game that fall far too short of the real-life experience of working on cars.The first mistake I noticed is the missing human element. In this game, you will find no blank stares or slow mumbles. There are no memorable answers to simple questions, such as people claiming to own a Honda Elantra. The customers usually know what's wrong with their cars and leave understandable notes on the work order, which allows you to quickly find and correct the current problem. I cannot begin to explain how far from reality this actually is. The another jab to the title of "simulator" comes from the ease of installation or removal of parts. As any grease monkey will testify, parts just don't come off that easily. I was also sad to find that there was no way to curse at the vehicle for being difficult. The mechanic you play as must be a ghost, as you'll find that starters, located next to the transmission, are installed and removed through the engine bay.Lastly, the cars are all clean. There is no grime to wash off, there are no fingernails lined with black grease. You will not find bandages on your arms and fingers because there are no impact or puncture wounds to heal. No mud, no oil, no antifreeze, no blood. It's all so easy.God I wish it was like this in reality.

Posted: July 19, 2014
												Great visuals, good music and sound.  Easy controls make it quite accessable.But after 3 hours of playing I've found it lacking in variety and the gameplay is too simple.Despite the name, this is a car puzzle game, not a detailed simulator.For me, someone who knows very little about cars, I got what a paid for - a learning game that has taught me more of the basics;  the names of various mechanical components and how they fit together, but I imagine anyone who already has that knowledge will lose intrest in this title very quickly.  Different vehicles in the base game all have the same components inside.The main challenge of the game is a real world one - where is the part I need to pull out? and what else to I need to remove first to get it out?   Figuring this out is rewarding.  But there's no need to pick the right tool for the job, simply click a part to remove it or click repeatedly to unscrew it.There's no time pressure either, no countdown clocks or waiting customers.  Having this as an option after the first few jobs might have spiced things up a bit.Your camera can fly through the transparent body of the car to give you a better view of what you're removing, which is fine except when, despite the fact you can see a part, you can't remove it because you entered this view from the engine rather than the wheel.  This is a little frustrating because the game lacks feedback.  A simple audio cue of your 'character' saying "Uh.  Can't reach that from here"  or "Whoops, no room under the car to pull that out."  might have prompted me to open the hood or raise the car on the lift rather looking around fruitlessly for a  prerequiste part to remove first.  Parts that are visible but inaccessable should have better visual cues, "greying out" when you mouse over them, etc.As the career progresses, you get access to better garages, I hope this will allow me to remove engine blocks and pull them apart.If you have children and you'd like to share your motorhead passion with them, this would be an excellent place to start, but if you tinker with real engines, this won't fire you up. Still recommended for the quality of the production but I'd love to see a "pro" mode that increases the complexity of the engines and other components.

The camera angles can get a little funky when you're tyring to move around the car but I chalk that up as an attempt at realism.  Since parts on real cars are often only accessible from certain areas but can be seen from others I can give it a pass.  The reparis are somewhat general but if you have a basic grasp of auto mechanics you'll enjoy this game.  Sometimes the programming fails, however, and forces you into a narrow order of operations that is less about reality and more about how the game is coded.  Don't expect to get your ASE certification from the game it's not that specific but the game will challenge you to figure out problems with little more than a customer complaint that says, " It won't start"Be sure to enable the cursor clipping option or the game will randomly dump to the desktop on a scene change.  Other than that it's just a great timesink for a gearhead.  I got it on sale and feel it's worth what I paid but not the regular price.I'd recommend the game to people interested in automotives that would like to get a basic understanding of what it means to do basic repairs and the thought process behind them.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 starts off in a garage as you take on the role of the Mechanic. The goal is simple: perform the tasks on the work order using your trusty wrench and diagnostic tools (including test drives), not to mention your two eyes to find and repair the various parts and make a profit.The game itself isn't terrible, the graphics are quite good and the gameplay is fluid enough, but the repetition and free-roaming aspect of the game can become tedius if not completely irritating at times. To give an example of this, take a work order that simply says "The car pulls to the right sometimes." You'll find yourself pulling the car apart to find the problem, then you need to walk to the computer to buy the new part, walk back, put everything back together and move on. Sometimes the simplest problem becomes a headache because you have to remove several parts to get to the part you need to replace.Walking around the car and having to work on it section by section can be a bit of a pain, but for simulation sake is pretty accurate enough to real life that it makes sense. Although, in a gaming aspect can just be viewed as a bit of a waste of time and makes some jobs a bit too long to be enjoyable. The fact that you can't create and build your own cars and sell them off is a bit of a letdown as well.All-in-all, if you want to remove bolts and replace parts all day long, this is your game. I would recommend getting it at a discounted price if you can. Although a nice little past-time game, long-term and replayability is definitely not on the books for this title. The potential is there but unfortunately it falls just short of a good simulator.Rating: D+

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Not a bad way to kill time but don't expect anything too challenging here. If you know a little about cars and like to tinker is it good fun and easy to diagnose and repair the cars. Real car mechanics / enthusiasts shouldn't expect much in the way of accuracy or simulation.  Some things are a little strange like when you take a brake caliper off and the pads are still there floating beside the rotor, or how you have to take apart an entire air intake all the way to the throttle body just to replace an air filter.But, it still is a good time waster.The test drive mode should have either been not included or it needs to be upgraded, badly. Every car drives the same no matter what the issue. I even took a car for a test drive that supposedly wouldn't start! Ok.. sure if you listen you can hear the brakes squeak on some cars but that is the only difference i have ever heard so far. The test driving just feels like a chore and the element of fun has worn off by the third or fourth time you have to do one.All in all, I'll play though it. I'm around 4 hours in and about 1/3 completed with the career.Final Thoughts: It's hard to call this a game. There isn't a lot of game aspects to it. If you like to teardown stuff and put it back together, this is a good diversion for what it is. The graphics are good, but I can hear my vid card run like it has never ran before, which sort of tells me that it could be optimized a little better. There are only a handful of cars and most of the time it will not matter which car it is because they all share most of the same components, so when you are tearing them down, there isn't much different between the cars.I know that is a lot of cons, but I still enjoy playing it.. It reminds me of when I was a child and wanted to take apart all of my own toy cars. For that alone I will give it an 8/10

Posted: February 11, 2014
												I found it difficult to recommend this game and equally difficult not to. I finally settled on recommending it because it seems to succeed at what it sat out to do. It is a competent simulator. You should plan on reading the steam forums a lot if you are not mechanically inclined or not familiar with what makes an automobile work. That being said, you also don't have to be an ASE Certified master technician to enjoy the game. You have an economy system with progression in the form of better equipment and money boosts. You do have to purchase the parts you intend to use so there is a failure state if you are not careful (you can reset scenarios though). During career you will advance from a small repair shop to a state of the art complex. Parts that you can interact with are highlighted and show colored “health” represented by a percentage meter. Some parts have to be removed to be examined. The parts that can be removed are usually highlighted and if you are required to remove a certain part to get to another they are shown in red to make things easier. An example would be removing tires to work on the brakes. There are also different views you can choose from removing the body rotating the camera and showing “health” of the parts. Graphical fidelity is competent but could have been better. Since this isn't a AAA title though I can accept it. It is not without its problems though. I do have experience and education behind me for automotive service and repair so I didn't really get hung up on any of the scenarios that I played. I can easily see where this game may be too advanced for beginners wanting to learn about cars and it is a shame that there is no hint system to speak of (or at least that I was able to find). My biggest complaint with the game is the navigation. I had to exit the “wheel” section, for example to access the “engine” area (like the transmission bell housing) which was clearly in view already. It made it unnecessarily convoluted and drawn out even though I knew exactly what I had to do.I would have liked to have seen more choice in tools and a way to torque bolts to the proper specs as well as some tire changing/balancing stations but that may just be because I’m really into this kind of work in real life. I would recommend this to anyone with a strong interest in the game but if your interest is only passing you may want to wait for a sale.

												100% Recommended at the $7 sale price. $20 for the regular price and I still think it's worth it. I'm 61/75 on the normal orders and still have 20 left on the offroad add-on.Gameplay is smooth on ultra settings, except I have OA and DOF disabled because of my old GeForce 9600 GSO and running 1600x900 native resolution.Game still looks very good with those settings.The camera can be bothersome at times, but you can click on any part near the part you actually need to focus the camera quickly. The only downfall is the repetative gameplay itself but it's still engaging and pushes you on to complete the order, and the next, and the next.Personally I wish there was more depth, like being able to actually delve into the engine, or replace U-Joints and smaller stuff. But I understand this game is meant for everyone and people that don't know a lot about cars could get lost.I would just like to see difficulty settings. Normal and Hardcore where Hardcore is much more mechanically inclined.All in all, I recommend this title.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												So this game is sort of a neat premise with not enough effort put into its execution. It is, as many have already pointed out, somewhat limited in scope. You click to unscrew bolts, you inspect the condition of the parts, you order new ones from the computer and you replace the old ones. Done. Occasionally you test-drive the cars on this one small ugly test course. So far, the insides of most cars I have repaied looked the same! If you get to work on a muscle car then the setup does change, but basically the insides only differ per type of car and not per car. All the major parts of a car are there but don't expect to be replacing some small stressed screw somehwere or repairing a crack in the windshield. This game does not go that deep.But since I know almost nothing about cars, it did teach me a thing or two about them so mission accomplished I guess.I recommend it but only if it's on sale. 20 euros is a bit too steep. The only thing this game really has going for it is its uniqueness, which is a shame because I think an in-dept car mechanic simulator would be an interesting game.

Posted: June 5, 2015
												I played a version of this game many many many  years (over a decade ) ago. It's pretty much the same except now there are work orders,a test drive section, a parts ordering mechanism,and a radio. Overall it's the same game. (but it was on sale for less than 3 bucks so what the hell I picked it up).Let me say this, as a simulator this game falls wayyyy short, I've never done a brake job that didn;t have caliper bracket bolts or a bracket for that matter so yeah not too realilistic there. The prices are very odd, there's no pressing out bearings (so far anyway) and one of the first 5 jobs i was supposed to test an alternator...well when I removed the thing it said 6% cheapest option was replacement, ordered part put it on, got the belt on, took the battery out (1%) cheapest option was repair (90 some dollars....what shop doesn't have a charger to  "repair" a battery for free?) put it all together went to close out the repair and low and behold it said to test alternator...what the ♥♥♥♥ does it matter now that i replaced it? and it wouldn't let me just check the condition of the old alternator... so ♥♥♥♥ that.Other things to note; the mouse is laggy in game, it has different speeds in different parts of the game i.e the menu, the game, the computer ordering , all different speeds incredibly frustrating. The test drive section is pretty pointless, I don't think I know of a single person who would want me to put their car through such strain after fixing it and it's clunky.In summary if you have an interest in working on cars but no knowledge this game is actually a decent tool to familiarize yourself with the components of the average automobile, the version I played so long ago went a long way in helping me memorize the main engine components of the average v8 of the era and this game is more advaned. But you're better off just working on cars to learn how. so yeah don't buy this unless it's super cheap and you have next to 0 car knowledge.

												Pretty sure this was a glitch on Valve's end, but I got this game in the PlayWay's Sim Bundle for $0.99. This was while the game was still on sale for $5.49 0.o. 6 hours later, (no sales rotations have occured, mind you), and that bundle price has risen to $16, with CMS2014 still being $5.49. Now then...Having got the game for $1, it's really great. I'm learning basic car parts really rapidly, and still having "fun" at the same time. However, the game's not perfect. The starting menu is all flashy and fancy, then you get in-game and everything looks rather bland. The way your character moves around is a little clunky, and the first few hours are spent trying to figure out everything with NO TUTORIAL beyond showing you how to change the radio station, raise the vehicle platform, and order parts online. No interactio with the vehicle is taught; you must figure it all out on your own.Overall, for $1, or even $5.49, it's a pretty nice deal if you're wanting to learn car parts, and what a mechanic job might be like. Posted: December 25, 2014
												Mechanic Simulator is about as close to simulating a mechanic as Goat Simulator is at making you a goat.  You're forced to use WASD and mouse look instead of right-click and drag to move your view.  It's archaic and cumberome to use.  There are some very big issues with the interface and movement of this game let alone the gameplay.  One of the first jobs includes a fuel filter replacement but there's no indication where it is because there are no fuel lines or evap lines leading you to it.  You're left searching with a horrible 3D view panel for a little box where no fuel goes.  This game is nothing like working on a real car.  If you've ever worked on a car and know what you are doing then this game is definitely not for you.  It has great potential to be a mechanic simulator but it needs a ton more work especially on the way you look around and select things.  Is it worth $5?  Barely.  I'd think $3 would be a fair price for a game that feels like it should still be in alpha development.

Posted: March 26, 2016
SHORT VERSION:If nothing else this game serves well as a casual time-killer. It doesn't offer very much in the way of a compelling narrative, nor any real progression, but the basic game mechanics are sound if a little repetitive. A basic working knowledge of cars is helpful, but in no way neccessary as the vehicle components are condensed and simplified.Overall I wouldn't reccomend this game, unless it is on sale. I don't think it's overy poor but I don't rate it as a game you should rush out and buy for being triple-A quality - in terms of gameplay OR graphics.EXPECT:Generic unlicenced vehicles, repetition, simple interface, solid graphics, lots of unbolting.DO NOT EXPECT:To feel blown away, variation, memorable moments, longevity, replay value, quality DLC, overly helpful job descriptions, absolute realism.LONG VERSION:For the first time since I started writing Steam reviews for games I find myself genuinely at a loss. The games I reviewed up to this point invoked something - whether it be emotion, nostalgia or a general sense of achievement. It's hard to convey feeling in analysing a simulator - by their very nature simulators are as far detached from human emotion as possible. They are clinical in their execution, even if they are not an entirely representative experience of their subject matter.This is the problem that I found with Car Mechanic Simulator 2014. While it is different (in the sense that most simulators deal with the operation of vehicles, with maintainence being a one-click afterthought) this game suffers from intense repetition which far outweighs the initial novelty value. Throughout the 'career mode' you are presented with vehicles in varying levels of disrepair. You are given some hints as to the problem (this is where a good working knowledge of what components do what in a car comes in useful), but in the end you have the tools to examine a car top to bottom and it all boils down to 'replace everything that's red'. There are diagnostic tracks and an on-board diagnostics tool, which are useful in quickly assessing the car's health or finding what you've missed. You can also test drive the car, though the car physics are pretty dull and listless, and a vehicle with inferior components seems to handle the same as one that has brand new parts rendering the whole process entirely useless.In terms of progression, you start in a tiny dingy garage with limited facilities before you automatically get upgraded until you have a full-size facility with the opportunity to perform brake/suspension tests and ECU tuning. You have no say in how and when you upgrade, it just seems to happen. There is also a series of 'skill upgrades' which makes parts cheaper, gives your more money per job, get automatic analysis on random parts or unbolt faster. All in all, the game's progression does not stand up to most others in the genre and seems quite limited - you can't buy other garages, hire other mechanics or do any sort of empire-building which would enhance the experience or, in the very least, give it some lasting appeal.It seems unfortunate that the gameplay can be condensed into two paragraphs, but honestly there is nothing else there. There are DLCs, which are thankfully free, which give a small extension to the experience. The 4x4 DLC will add the Bolthorn Wanderer (what appears to be an unlicenced Jeep) with some associated themed repairs (i.e. customers who've been off-roading and royally messed up the suspension) and the 1/4-Mile Drag DLC which adds jobs to make cars achieve a certain time over, you guessed it, a quarter-mile drag. That's it. The same dull physics plague the 1/4-mile test drives making the whole DLC uninspired (I got bored after 3 jobs).Lastly I will touch on the graphics, which are fairly decent and do the job without any serious excitment. The interface is simple if a little clunky. The camera is nausea-inducing at times, moving around as you select and remove/replace parts making keeping it focussed on bolting/unbolting somewhat infuriating. That's it. Nothing else to report.FINAL WORDThis was tough to write. There is so little content spread over a long game span with a lot of repetition. It is very easy to fall into the trap of the 'just one more job.. just one more job' mentality, but you won't feel any more accomplished than when you started.This is very much a borderline game - I really wish there was something between Reccomend and Not Reccomend because this game embodies that grey area. It isn't offensively bad to play but I wouldn't urge you to go out and buy it either. Just wait until it's heavily discounted - your wallet WILL NOT forgive you. In that sense I will NOT reccomend this, if only to stress the importance of patience.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												Let me preface this by saying that I love this game; I wouldn't have played it for this many hours if I didn't. I should also mention that I used to work as an apprentice mechanic. I tried my best not to nit-pick every minutia of the game, but it will probably seem otherwise to people with no automotive knowledge. Trust me; even if some of the details I mention seem small, they are still significant. This review is intended both as constructive criticism for the developers and as a cautionary tale to any would-be purchaser.This is a great little puzzle(?)/simulation game and in my eyes, it's worth every cent of what I paid for it. That being said, there are a whole host of kinks that need to be ironed out of the "clunky" and sometimes-infuriating gameplay:- My inventory filled up with crap really fast, since I didn't get around to selling all the junk parts until I had the next car apart and new "green", "yellow" and "orange" parts mixed into the inventory as well. It would have been really nice to have a "sell all junk parts" button.- Sometimes it's "fiddly" to get to small things like spark plugs (the issue was compounded by the fact that I don't have a top-shelf gaming PC, so the game always lagged a bit.)- Sometimes I couldn't stamp the car as "repaired", even though there wasn't a single red part on it. I soon figured out that I had to put the EXACT PARTS IN THE EXACT PLACES they started in. It was really annoying and I had to start several levels over because of this. I can appreciate that without this, the used parts system cannot work. However, if brake pads and bushings were sold in "sets" like in real life and brake calipers were separated by right/front, left/front, etc, the issue would be entirely eliminated with the used parts system intact.- I have to unbolt the entire exhaust system, starting at the muffler, just to get to the manifold. WHAT THE HELL? The exhaust pieces should be "independently" and not "sequentially" removable...- The cursor does not centre after moving to a menu (it stays centred when moving around, but jumps to a corner when you enter a menu or work on the car... This gets reeeeeeally annoying after a while.)- Transmission extraction from the top of the car, seriously??? I have never, ever, ever, EVER seen that done (unless the engine is coming out with the transmission, which is not possible in this game.) This detail is especially annoying on rear- or all-wheel drive cars. You have to take three extra unnecessary steps, walking over to the lift button, lowering the car, walking back to the hood before finally taking the transmission out, rather than simply taking the transmission and starter out from the bottom of the car, like any normal person.- Switching between "assemble" and "disassemble" is another great time-waster. I'd have loved to just have them merged together, with an outline of the part to be assembled appearing in the place of the part that was removed. Heck, it would also be nice not to have to move the camera around while you're working on the car (sometimes the camera spazzes out so badly with its zooming-in-and-out business that the bolt you want to loosen flies clear off-screen and you have to move the camera around some more...) A complete view of all the parts, à la "Street Rod", would have been a lot easier.If you're willing to look past all of this minor to moderate awfulness, however; by all means, buy this game right now. You will spend many joyous hours planning, diagnosing, analysing and just plain screwing around.

												6/10I got the game after they freshly released it and always waited for their little DLCs they've released but the game has some serious issues that are annoying but not a real death sentence.Positive things:- The job variety is alright. In the story mode you dont have to do the same thing twice in a row, you get to see different approaches.- The graphics are "alright" for a studio like this.- Many parts to disassemble. Just had the fun on a mission to take a whole car apart and get it back together.- Tuning possible but very limited.- Car class variety from vans over sedans to sports cars.- Chance to order used parts and brush them up to save money.Negative aspects:- The tuning itself is set as a minigame that makes absolutely no sense. I am not a car mechanic, dont intent to become one but I cant imagine that you sit infront of a screen and move a damn flipchart of an EEPROM around until the percentage matches.- Very poor physics in the test drive. Every customer nearly needs the test drive to be sure that the car is working but like the game is made it just does not represent anything, the car feels like a fish in a god damn tank.- The DLCs dont really brought that much of content to be satisfied. - Credit is a one time thing in the whole game, seriously?- Double Monitor use always throws you out of the game when your mouse leaves the game, never have that happen in other games.- No customer wants to keep their car parts, makes the form and the difficult of the game pretty low.- The race track is just a horror with the physics as well.Potential that could have been used in my eyes but well...I still enjoyed it, nothing outstanding, can pay that low price for it.

												I wanted to like this game, being a fan of simluators in general.  And having worked on more than my share of cars in my day.  But it just falls short.  The tutorial is woefully inadequate, especially if the player has no prior knowledge of car anatomy so to speak.  Silly things too, like who changes a starter from the engine compartment?  Or since when is an oil filter on top of the engine block?  But I could forgive those things, if there was some challenge to the game, besides playing hide and seek with the parts, but diagnosing problems is limited to examining items, the test drives offer no actual benefit, yes, I wanted common mechanical issue sounds, thunking of a bad shock over bumps, clicking of a bad CV during turns etc.  Overall I'm giving this game a 3/10.

Posted: April 25
												I got this game at a 90% discount during a sale.All biases aside. It is fun, and as you progress you do get more out of it, but as you begin in the career mode, it starts off smoothly and easy but then the second part comes in and it feels tedious. Albeit. I had high expectations that were soon overruled.The game does state that you are starting from the bottom to the top and I completely ignored that once I bought the game. But like any game, when you give it the time or enough love you wil most definately be able to enjoy it in the long run. But here are MY cons. In all honesty, it does not fall in a modern first person enviroment where you'd believe you'd have complete freedom - such as the ability to pick up stuff with hands and inspect them that way or even be able to punch tangible objects and blast them across the room. Music is good. But filled with so much electro dance music (I enjoyed the ones which were chill), and some rock (which I enjoyed). For me, I want driving music like 80s influenced or originated songs.I'm just disappointed that they don't have a crouching feature, let alone the player model having hands in a first person enviroment. I just want to grab and throw stuff around. I'd still recommend this game, for it is the complete edition of the title - so you still get a lot out of it, but I still feel it has so much more potential. And unlike its successors, it does not feel at all like a simulator that demands more (money) from you, so that's good.Note again. I got this during a sale - and if you do see this on sale, try it out but don't let your expectations drive you. Its not in its entirety close to replayable fun.
